Response.BaseQuestion: Introduction
Response.Content:
Hello, I'm Darieth, and I want to welcome you to our interactive Cancer Care Navigation Coach. You may be coming to this program after your doctor has told you that you have lung cancer; or, you may be a caregiver of someone who has lung cancer. No matter what has brought you here, I want you to keep one very important thing in mind as you use this program. New treatments for lung cancer are being discovered and tested through clinical trials all the time. And these discoveries are helping people with lung cancer live longer and better lives than ever before. Yes, this is a very serious disease, and yes, it can be life-threatening, but there are treatments for every stage of lung cancer that will help you in your fight against this disease.
We developed this program at Highmark to make it easy for you to get all the information you need when you need it. We know facing a cancer diagnosis is scary There is a lot of new information to take in, important decisions to make, and you probably have many questions. There's a lot on your plate, but don't let it overwhelm you: you have a Cancer Care Team that will be coaching you through it, step-by-step, and telling you what you can expect at each stage of your journey. Your Cancer Care Team includes the many skilled health care providers you will see during treatment, as well as myself, and other online guides that are available 24/7.

Response.BaseQuestion: When should I tell my doctor about new symptoms after cancer treatment has ended?
Response.Content:
After your cancer treatment, you can expect to have some lingering side effects such as
• Fatigue • Memory and thinking problems • Pain • Tingling or numbness in your feet and hands • Lymphedema • Mouth or teeth problems • Changes in weight or eating habits, • Trouble swallowing • Bladder or bowel control problems • Problems with sexual function
It is important to talk openly with your healthcare providers about these issues. They can not only help you to relieve these side effects, but they can also help address concerns about whether these side effects signal the return of your cancer. For more information on these long-term side effects and how to manage them, look in the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I use complimentary medicine?
Response.Content:
Complimentary or alternative medicine includes a variety of practices that are used in addition to the treatments that your doctor prescribes to treat your cancer. For instance, meditation, yoga, massage, and acupuncture may be used to help reduce pain, lower anxiety and improve mood. Things like aromatherapy, special diets, and vitamins or herbal supplements are also considered alternative medicine.
If you are thinking about using any alternative medicine therapies during or after your cancer treatment, talk to your doctor first. Even if something is described as homeopathic, all natural, or organic, it can still interfere with your treatment or cause dangerous side effects. There is more information on alternative medicine in the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a CT Scan?
Response.Content:
CT Scans are commonly called "CAT Scans" The Letters CT stand for computed tomography. This type of scan uses x-rays and a computer to make a three-dimensional picture of the inside of your body. These pictures show where and how big a tumor is.
CT scans themselves are painless. You will lie down on the table attached to the scanner, then the radiology technician will make the table move into a correct position for your scan. Sometimes a dye is used to make the picture clearer. This is called CT with contrast. The dye can be injected into your vein using a needle, or you may be given the dye in a pill that you will swallow.
You may need to have more than one CT scan. Because each CT scan exposes you to X-rays, which are a form of radiation, doctors sometimes use a CT scan called LDCT, which stands for low-dose computed tomography. This type of CT scan uses lower doses of x-rays and so that you're not exposed to as much radiation.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are nodules or masses?
Response.Content:
Nodules are small, unusual spots on the lungs that may or may not be cancer. Masses are unusual spots that are larger than 3 centimeters which is about the diameter of a quarter.
Not all nodules or masses are lung cancer. About 60% are caused by other things, like infections, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease or COPD, calcium build-up in the arteries leading to the heart, a weakened section of artery that bulges out, or cancer that has spread from other parts of the body to the lung.
Nodules can also be benign, or non-cancerous tumors called hamartomas that do not grow and spread like cancer

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a surgical biopsy?
Response.Content:
Surgical biopsy is the sampling of lung tissue through an incision in the chest.
This type of biopsy is done in the hospital in an operating room. Like other surgeries, you will need to stop eating and drinking at least 8 hours before the surgery. You will be given general anesthesia through an IV so that you are fully asleep during surgery. Often during the procedure, the tissue that is removed is examined by the pathologist while you are still in surgery so that doctors can remove more tissue if necessary without another operation.
There are different types of surgical biopsies. In a thoracoscopic biopsy, an endoscope, or thin hollow tube, is inserted through the incision in your chest. A camera and biopsy tools are inserted through the endoscope to allow the surgeon to examine and collect tissue for testing. This may also be called video-assisted thoracic surgery or VATS biopsy. Your doctor may also remove nodules or other tissue at the same time.
In an open biopsy is your doctor makes an incision in the skin on your chest and removes a piece of lung tissue. Depending on what the pathologist sees when they look at the removed tissue under the microscope, your surgeon may do other procedures such as the removal of a lung lobe. These biopsies generally require at least an overnight hospital stay.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a biopsy?
Response.Content:
A biopsy is a procedure that removes cells from the tumor so that the cells can be looked at under a microscope to determine if they are cancerous.
There are different kinds of biopsies. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) uses a very thin, hollow needle attached to a syringe to take a small amount of fluid or very small pieces of tissue from the tumor. If you're having a fine needle aspiration, your skin will be numbed with a shot of local pain killer before the doctor makes a small cut and inserts the needle into the tumor. Sometimes doctors use a CT scan or ultrasound to guide the needle to the site of the tumor.
Another type of biopsy is a core biopsy. Needles used in a core biopsy are slightly larger than those used in fine needle aspiration. A core biopsy removes a small piece of tissue. You will be given one or more shots of pain killer where the biopsy is being done to numb your skin.
You can usually go home the same day after fine needle and core biopsies. Biopsies that cannot be done with a needle may be done surgically or through bronchoscopy.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is surgery used to treat lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Surgery may be done to confirm a cancer diagnosis, to determine the cancer stage, or to completely remove tumors in the early stages. In some cases, surgery can also be done to remove metastases.
When a tumor is removed, the nearby lymph nodes and a small amount of normal tissue surrounding the tumor is taken as well. This border of healthy tissue is called the tumor margin. The tumor margin is examined by a pathologist to see if it contains any cancer cells. If there are no cancer cells in the tumor margin, it is most likely that all of the cancer has been removed. However, if there are cancer cells in the margin, it may mean that not all of the tumor was removed and you may need to have another surgery, or chemotherapy or radiation to remove or kill the remaining cancer cells.
There is a myth that having surgery on a tumor allows the cancer to spread by breaking cancer cells off from the tumor. Surgery does not cause cancer to spread. There are many different types of surgeries that doctors do, depending on the size and location of the tumor. Look in the related questions area to your right to learn about different types of surgeries to remove cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do pathologists diagnose cancer after surgery?
Response.Content: After surgery or a biopsy, the cells that doctors remove will be looked at under a microscope by a pathologist to see if they are cancer cells. If the pathologist does find cancer cells, they will try to determine what type of cancer you have so that the oncologist will know what treatment to give you.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is staging?
Response.Content:
In addition to the main types of cancers and their subtypes, doctors also describe cancer in stages.
Stages describe where the original tumor is located in the body, the size of the tumor, whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes, and whether the cancer has spread to a different part of the body, or metastasized. This information helps your doctor plan the best treatment for you.
Cancer is staged using the TNM method, which stands for Tumor, Nodes and Metastases. You may hear health care providers talk about cancer as stage one through four, and see stages written using roman numerals, like this and with the letters "A" and "B". For more information on staging, look in the Resource Area and the related questions on this page.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is lung cancer staged?
Response.Content:
Based on your physical exam, imaging tests like CT or PET scans and blood tests, your doctor will give you a "clinical stage" which estimates the extent of your cancer.
Additional testing of lymph nodes after surgery can give your doctor a more precise idea of the extent of your cancer. This is called the "pathologic stage."
The pathologic stage may be the same as the clinical stage, or it may show that your cancer has spread more than expected. The tests and procedures that doctors use to tell what stage your cancer is will depend on the cancer site and your health.

Response.BaseQuestion: What should I know about getting treatment for cancer?
Response.Content:
Getting treatment for cancer can place many unexpected demands on your time and energy and those of your caregivers as well, so it's important to prepare by getting as much information as possible about how your treatment may affect your life.
When you talk to your doctor about treatment options, make sure you find out how often and for how long you will need to go into the treatment center, and what kinds of tests you will need and how often. Before you start treatment, you may want to check with your employer to find out what sick leave you are eligible for. Your treatment schedule and side effects from treatment may affect whether or not you are able to continue to work during treatment.
You may find that you need help with transportation, keeping track of medications, appointments and all the paperwork that comes with a cancer diagnosis. Look in the related questions area for tips on how to manage these important details while you're receiving treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is lung cancer treated?
Response.Content:
Your doctor will recommend treatment for your cancer based on what type of cancer you have, where it is located, whether or where it has spread, and what genetic markers it has, as well as your general health and any other conditions you may have.
Lung cancer may be treated with chemotherapy, surgery, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, and supportive care, or a combination of these therapies.
Keep in mind that all forms and stages of cancer can be treated, but the goals of treatment may be different depending on the type of cancer you have and what stage it is. Treatments for some early stage cancers aim to cure the cancer, meaning that the person could hope to be cancer free after treatment is complete.
For patients with later stage cancers, sometimes the best goal of treatment may be to extend life or reduce symptoms and side effects rather than trying to cure the patient's cancer. In these stages, supportive care has been shown to increase quality of life as well as extending life when compared to treatment with more aggressive options such as chemotherapy or radiation.
In deciding what treatment is best for your type of cancer, your oncologist will follow treatment guidelines agreed on by national cancer experts.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is immunotherapy?
Response.Content:
Immunotherapy describes treatments that help your immune system fight your cancer. Immunotherapy is also called biologic therapy or biotherapy.
Your immune system helps keep you healthy by recognizing and destroying cells that can make you sick, like viruses and germs. Cancer cells are sometimes overlooked by the immune system because they are made by your body, so they are not seen as "foreign."
One type of immunotherapy, called monoclonal antibodies, works by marking cancer cells for destruction by your immune system. Another type of immunotherapy, called immune checkpoint inhibitors boost your immune system, allowing it to go all out in destroying suspicious cells that it might not normally attack. There are other immunotherapy drugs, called non-specific immunotherapies, that make your immune system stronger and better able to fight cancer cells.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is chemotherapy?
Response.Content:
Chemotherapy medications work by stopping the cancer cells from growing and dividing. Chemotherapy may be given by an intravenous or IV tube and needle, called an infusion. Some chemotherapy medications are given as an injection like a shot or can be taken in pill form. You may take one chemotherapy medication, or a combination of medications depending on your cancer and what stage it is.
The side effects of chemotherapy depend on the individual, the type of medication and the dose your doctor has prescribed you. They can include fatigue, nausea and vomiting, loss of appetite, hair loss, low blood counts, mouth sores and an increased risk of infection.
I encourage you to talk to your doctor or nurse before starting your treatment, so you know what the most common side effects are from the medications you are taking and when they can occur.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is radiation therapy?
Response.Content:
Radiation therapy uses powerful x-rays to destroy cancer cells. This treatment is not used to treat widespread cancer because radiation damages normal cells as well as cancer cells. When this happens, side effects can occur, such as skin changes, fatigue, and nausea.
You may also have other side effects depending on the part of your body being treated. Look in the related questions area on this page for side effects from radiation treatment to specific areas of your body.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is chemoradiation?
Response.Content: Chemoradiation or chemoradiotherapy is the use of both chemotherapy and radiation therapy in the same treatment cycle. There are several benefits to treatment with combined chemotherapy and radiation. This treatment method can help to preserve the structure and functions of organs compared with surgery. Also, chemotherapy can improve how well radiation treatment works. And while radiation works to kill cancer cells locally, chemotherapy can kill cancer cells that have traveled to other locations in the body.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are targeted therapies?
Response.Content:
Monoclonal Antibodies and anti-angiogenesis drugs are both considered targeted therapies. Each type of targeted therapy works differently, but all interfere with the ability of the cancer cell to grow, divide, repair or to communicate with other cells. They work by targeting specific features of cancer cells that normal cells don't have. This allows targeted therapies to attack the cancer cells without damaging the normal cells.
All medications can cause some side effects. Look in the related questions area to find out more about what side effects you may have when taking a targeted therapy drug. If your doctor has prescribed targeted therapies for you, you may also want to ask them about supportive care options.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is adenocarcinoma?
Response.Content:
Adenocarcinoma of the lung, also called pulmonary adenocarcinoma is a form of non-small cell lung cancer.
Adenocarcinoma is usually found in the outer parts of the lung. This type of cancer grows more slowly and forms smaller masses than the other types of non-small cell lung cancer. However, adenocarcinoma tends to spread widely at an early stage.
About 40% of lung cancers are adenocarcinomas. This type of lung cancer occurs mainly in current or former smokers, but it is also the most common type of lung cancer seen in non-smokers. It is more common in women than in men, and it is more likely to occur in younger people than other types of lung cancer. For more information on adenocarcinoma, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is squamous-cell carcinoma?
Response.Content:
Squamous-cell carcinoma of the lung is a type of non-small cell lung cancer. This type of lung cancer may first show up as abnormal cells in the mucus or the cells lining the airways many years before a tumor develops. These cells may be seen in a cytologic smear test or biopsy of cells lining the airways. When tumors do form, they are usually found in the larger airways of the lung called the bronchi.
This type of cancer is difficult to detect on x-rays and usually causes no symptoms until it starts to block the large airways and causes infection, collapses part of the lung, or spreads to other parts of the body.
This type of non-small cell lung cancer may spread to the lymph nodes in the chest early in the disease, it spreads more slowly outside the chest than other common types of lung cancer.
Squamous-cell carcinoma is more common in men than in women, and is more common in people who smoke than most other types of lung cancer. For more information on squamous cell carcinoma, look in the Resources area of this page.

Squamous-cell carcinoma is more common in men than in women and is more common in people who smoke than most other types of lung cancer. For more information on squamous cell carcinoma, look in the Resources area of this page.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is non-small cell large cell carcinoma?
Response.Content:
Non-small cell large cell carcinoma, also called large cell lung cancer, is a form of non-small cell cancer. Large cell lung cancers make up between 5% and 10% of all lung cancers.
They usually start in the outer areas of the lungs. Because of their location, common early symptoms of lung cancer, such as a cough that won't go away and coughing up blood may not happen until later. Instead, early symptoms of large cell cancer include extreme tiredness, mild shortness of breath, and achiness in your back shoulder, or chest. They can also cause fluid to develop in the space between the lung and the chest wall. This can cause pain in your chest or side that worsens with a deep breath.
Large cell carcinomas can also make hormone-like chemicals that can cause what is called paraneoplastic syndrome. Paraneoplastic syndrome can make you feel extremely tired, cause loss of appetite and weight loss. Other symptoms include weakness or clumsiness, changes in taste, smell, or sight, and problems with memory or thinking skills, or even sleep. These symptoms are often over looked because they can be the result of other health problems. This type of lung cancer tends to grow quickly and spread earlier than some other forms of non-small cell lung cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are mouth sores (Mucositis)?
Response.Content:
Mouth sores from cancer treatment are called oral mucositis.
Chemotherapy and radiation kill cancer cells, but they also damage the cells lining the gastro-intestinal tract, which goes from the mouth to the anus. This causes the lining of the mouth to break down.
Oral mucositis is one of the most common and often most difficult side effects of chemotherapy and radiation treatment. It can cause pain and make it difficult to eat and get enough nutrition, and can increase your risk of infection. Mucositis can not only impact your quality of life, it can also delay or limit treatment doses. For this reason, it is important that you let your health care team know as soon as you notice any of the symptoms of mucositis.
Signs and symptoms of mucositis include: • Red, shiny, or swollen mouth and gums • Blood in the mouth • Sores in the mouth or on the gums or tongue • Soreness or pain in the mouth or throat • Difficulty swallowing or talking • Feeling of dryness, mild burning, or pain when eating food • Soft, whitish patches or pus in the mouth or on the tongue • Increased mucus or thicker saliva in the mouth.
Again, tell your health care team if you have any issues with sores in your mouth. Treating them early can save you a lot of pain and discomfort.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is cancer of unknown primary origin?
Response.Content: Cancer of unknown primary origin is how doctors describe cancer that has spread to a different part of the body, when they cannot tell where the cancer first began. About 3-5 percent of all people with invasive cancer have cancer of unknown primary origin.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I prevent mucositis?
Response.Content:
Mucositis is very common in people getting chemotherapy or radiation, and most people will have at least some mouth sores over the course of their treatment. Your health care team will do everything they can to help prevent mucositis while you're in treatment, but there are steps you can take to reduce mucositis as well.
Before treatment, see a dentist who deals with cancer patients. If you need any dental work, such as a tooth extraction or cavities filled, it should be done at least one month before you start therapy so that your mouth can heal completely.
Good oral care, including brushing and flossing regularly, can help prevent or decrease the severity of mucositis and, just as important, help prevent infection. Use a soft bristle toothbrush and mild tasting toothpastes with fluoride, and brush your teeth after each meal or at least 2 to 3 times each day. If you experience sensitivity or mouth sores, you may need to use foam toothbrushes with an antibacterial rinse. You should also gently floss your teeth only once daily. Rinsing your mouth regularly with salt water after meals and at bedtime is one of the best and most cost effective ways to removing debris and keep your mouth moist and clean.
You should also avoid alcohol and spicy, hot, or acidic foods like lemons. Also avoid coarse foods that can damage the lining of your mouth, like very dry toast. Drink more liquids and try to include foods high in protein in your diet.
If you smoke, it is extremely important that you stop. Your doctor may be able to prescribe medications to help you.
Keep lips moist with moisturizers, but avoid using products with petroleum jelly, like Vaseline, because they can increase the risk of infection.
And, if you wear dentures, make sure they fit properly and remove them whenever possible to expose your gums to air. You may need to stop wearing your dentures if your mouth sores are severe.
It is important to keep ahead of mucositis to prevent it from becoming worse and delaying your treatment. Alert your health care team as soon as you notice any of the symptoms of mucositis so that they can help you keep it from getting worse.

Response.BaseQuestion: Question 004 What stage is your cancer?
Response.Content: Have you been told what stage your cancer is?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stage I non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Stage I lung cancer is a small tumor, less than 4 centimeters, that has not spread to any lymph nodes or to any area outside the lung where the tumor is. Stage I tumors can usually be completely removed by a surgeon. Doctors may also use the letters "A" and "B" to describe how large the tumor is.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stage I non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Stage I lung cancer is a small tumor, less than 4 centimeters, that has not spread to any lymph nodes or to any area outside the lung where the tumor is. Stage I tumors can usually be completely removed by a surgeon. Doctors may also use the letters "A" and "B" to describe how large the tumor is.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stage II non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Stage II lung cancer tumors are between 4.1cm and 7cm in size, or about 1 and a half to -2 3/4 inches. In this stage the cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes. There may also be a small second cancerous nodule close to the larger tumor in the same lobe of the lung. The cancer may also have grown into some of the areas around the lung such as the visceral pleura, main bronchus, or chest wall. Sometimes these tumors can be removed by surgeons, but patients may also need additional treatments.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stage II non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Stage II lung cancer tumors are between 4.1cm and 7cm in size, or about 1 and a half to -2 3/4 inches. In this stage the cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes. There may also be a small second cancerous nodule close to the larger tumor in the same lobe of the lung. The cancer may also have grown into some of the areas around the lung such as the visceral pleura, main bronchus, or chest wall. Sometimes these tumors can be removed by surgeons, but patients may also need additional treatments.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Stage III non-small cell lung cancer describes tumors that are larger than 7 cm, which is about 2 3/4 inches wide or have spread to one or more lymph nodes in the chest, grown into parts of the body close to the lungs such as the diaphragm or the heart, mediastinum, trachea, or the esophagus Non-small cell lung cancer may also be diagnosed as stage III if there is a second nodule further away from the main tumor in a different lobe of the same lung.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Stage III non-small cell lung cancer describes tumors that are larger than 7 cm, which is about 2 3/4 inches wide or have spread to one or more lymph nodes in the chest, grown into parts of the body close to the lungs such as the diaphragm or the heart, mediastinum, trachea, or the esophagus Non-small cell lung cancer may also be diagnosed as stage III if there is a second nodule further away from the main tumor in a different lobe of the same lung.

Response.BaseQuestion: Deleted
What is stage IV non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: When lung cancer reaches stage IV, that means it has spread to both lungs, the fluid surrounding the lung or heart, or to distant parts of the body such as the liver, bones, brain or adrenal glands.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stage IV non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: When lung cancer reaches stage IV, that means it has spread to both lungs, the fluid surrounding the lung or heart, or to distant parts of the body such as the liver, bones, brain or adrenal glands.

Response.BaseQuestion: Answer to question 005 I don't know what stage cancer
Response.Content: If you don't know what stage your cancer is, ask your doctor. When you find out, you can update your personal profile by clicking on your username. In the meantime, we can go over general information about cancer stages and treatments.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is recurrent cancer?
Response.Content: Recurrent cancer is cancer that has come back after treatment and after a period of time when no cancer can be found using scans. The same cancer may come back where it first started or somewhere else in the body. Recurrence is common after treatment of lung cancer. Treatment depends on what treatments you've had before, where the recurrence is, and what your physical condition is.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before stages I and II non-small cell lung cancer
Response.Content:
Before treatment for stages I and II, doctors may do additional tests.
Some tests you might have include: Pulmonary function tests to show how well your lungs are working. A bronchoscopy to look at the airways in your lungs, A biopsy of lymph nodes in your lungs to show whether or not the cancer has spread, And, a PET or CT scan. You may also have an MRI scan of the brain to find out if the cancer has spread there.
If doctors find that the cancer has spread to other parts of the body, it may change your diagnosis to a different stage and change the type of treatment that your doctor recommends.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for stage I and II non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Treatment for non-small cell lung cancer at stages I and II is generally surgery to remove the tumor. The type of surgery your doctor will do depends on where the tumor is located and how big it is.
Surgeons remove the tumor and some of the healthy tissue around it. The healthy tissue surrounding the tumor is called the "margin." The removed tissue will be looked at under a microscope to see how wide the margin of healthy tissue is. Doctors like to see a wide margin of healthy tissue around the tumor when it is removed because that means it is likely that they were successful in removing all of the cancer cells. If the margin of healthy tissue is narrow, your doctor may recommend another surgery to try to remove all the cancer cells, or radiation or chemotherapy to kill any remaining cancer cells.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for stage I and II non-small cell lung cancer? (2)
Response.Content:
Your doctor will also remove or take samples of lymph nodes in your chest, called the mediastinal lymph nodes. The tissue from your lymph nodes will be looked at under a microscope by a pathologist to find out whether there are any cancer cells in the lymph nodes.
If there are no cancer cells found in the lymph nodes in your chest, the doctor will recommend that you have an exam every 6-12 months that includes a physical exam, a chest CT scan and blood tests to look for signs of cancer.
If cancer cells are found in the lymph nodes, you may also have chemotherapy and radiation therapy after surgery. This is called adjuvant therapy, which means that it is in addition to surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for stage I and II non-small cell lung cancer? (3)
Response.Content: In some cases, traditional surgery is not possible. This may be because of the location of the tumor, or because you are too sick or weak to have surgery. In these cases, doctors may use other methods to destroy the tumor such as radiofrequency ablation, cryotherapy and stereotactic ablative radiotherapy also called SABR.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment of stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer
Response.Content:
Before treatment for Stage IIIA lung cancer, doctors may do additional tests.
Pulmonary function tests show how well your lungs are working. A bronchoscopy looks at the branching airways in your lungs, a biopsy of lymph nodes in your lungs can show whether or not the cancer has spread, and a PET or CT scan may be required. An MRI scan with contrast of your spine and chest will show doctors whether there are any tumors that are close to your spine or any major blood vessels. You may also have a MRI scan of the brain, to find out if the cancer has spread there.
Depending on what your doctor finds during these tests your diagnosis may change to a different stage and this may affect the type of treatment that your doctor recommends.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment of stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer? (1)
Response.Content: Treatment for stage IIIA lung cancer depends on where the tumor is, how big it is, and what other parts of the lungs or nearby organs are involved.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment of stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer? (2)
Response.Content:
For tumors located in the top upper right area of the lungs, called a superior sulcus tumor, doctors usually recommend chemoradiation before surgery.
After chemoradiation, doctors may do more CT and PET scans to find out if the tumor can be removed with traditional surgery. If it can, you will have surgery followed by chemotherapy. If the tumor is unresectable, that is, if doctors believe it cannot be removed, you will be treated with chemoradiation.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment of stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer? (3)
Response.Content: Sometimes tumors that have grown into the chest wall, an airway or the lining between the lungs and the rest of the chest cannot be operated on. In this situation, doctors recommend chemoradiation.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment of stage IIIB non-small cell lung cancer.
Response.Content:
Before treatment for Stage IIIB lung cancer, doctors may do additional tests.
Pulmonary function tests show how well your lungs are working. A PET or CT scan may be done from the base of your skull to your knees, or your whole body and a brain MRI scan with contrast will show doctors whether the cancer has spread to more distant parts of your body.
In a thoracoscopy, the thin, flexible tube, called a thoracoscope, is inserted through a small incision in the chest. This allows the surgeon to see inside the lungs, mediastinum, or the area between the lungs, and the pleura which is the membrane covering the lungs and lining the chest.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment of stage IIIB non-small cell lung cancer (2)
Response.Content:
Doctors will also want to do biopsies of lymph nodes and other tissue in and around your lungs, to see whether or not the cancer has spread locally.
Some biopsies can be taken using a long thin needle that is inserted through the skin. This is called a thin needle aspiration biopsy. A thicker needle is used to get a larger sample, called a core needle biopsy.
Some biopsies are done using a bronchoscope, which is a thin tube that is slid down your airway and has a camera and light on the end, as well as tools that take samples of tissue for the pathologist to look at under a microscope. Doctors use an ultrasound, a picture of your insides made using sound waves, to help guide the bronchoscope to where they want to get tissue samples. These procedures are called Esophageal Ultrasound Guided biopsies.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment of stage IIIB non-small cell lung cancer (3)
Response.Content:
Other biopsies require doctors to make incisions -- cuts in the skin -- so that they can get samples of lymph nodes that cannot be reached using a bronchoscope.
A mediastinoscopy is surgery to look at the inside of the upper chest between and in front of the lungs. This area is called the mediastinum.
During the test, a doctor makes a small cut, or incision, in the neck just above the breastbone or on the left side of the chest next to the breastbone. Then the doctor places a thin scope in the opening. A tissue sample, or biopsy, can be collected through the scope and then looked at under a microscope for lung problems. These problems might include infection, inflammation, or cancer.
The lymph nodes just above the collar bones are called the supraclavicular lymph nodes. These nodes are sometimes biopsied through an incision as well.
Depending on what your doctor finds during these tests your diagnosis may change to a different stage and this may affect the type of treatment that your doctor recommends.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for stage IIIB non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Treatment for stage IIIB cancer is typically chemoradiation.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer (1)
Response.Content:
Before treatment for stage IV non-small cell lung cancer, tests will be done to determine where it has spread and how to best treat it. Thoracentesis or pericardiocentesis involves using a needle to withdraw fluid from the chest area around the lungs or heart. The fluid is then looked at under a microscope to see if there are any cancer cells in it.
Another test, called Thoracoscopy uses a thin, flexible tube, called a thoracoscope, which is inserted through a small incision in the chest. A very small camera on the thoracoscope allows the surgeon to see the lungs, the area between the lungs called the mediastineum, and the membrane covering the lungs and lining the chest cavity, called the pleura.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer (2)
Response.Content: If the fluid is positive for cancer cells, it can be dangerous to the heart. The fluid will be drained if necessary using a small catheter, pleurodoesis, or pericardial window.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for stage IV non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Stage IV non-small cell lung cancer treatment depends on where in the lung or other part of the body the cancer has spread.
Cancer that has spread from one lung to the other, into the space surrounding the lungs, or into the fluid around lung or heart may be treated with surgery, or radiation therapy or both.
If there is a separate tumor in the same lobe as the original tumor, or in a different lobe on the same side of the lung, surgery is recommended to remove the tumors. Surgery may be followed by chemotherapy and/or chemoradiation or radiation treatment depending on whether the pathologist finds cancer cells in the border around the tissue that is removed from the lung.
Although it is rare, lung cancer that has spread to only one other part of the body outside of the chest may be treated with surgery, radiation or both. When lung cancer spreads outside of the chest area, it usually spreads to more than one location, in these cases, treatment depends on features of the tumor cells called mutations and biomarkers.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for stage IV non-small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Stage IV non-small cell lung cancer treatment depends on where in the lung or other part of the body the cancer has spread. Cancer that has spread from one lung to the other, into the space surrounding the lungs, or into the fluid around lung or heart may be treated with surgery, or radiation therapy or both. If there is a separate tumor in the same lobe as the original tumor, or in a different lobe on the same side of the lung, surgery is recommended to remove the tumors. Surgery may be followed by chemotherapy and/or chemoradiation or radiation treatment depending on whether the pathologist finds cancer cells in the border around the tissue that is removed from the lung. Although it is rare, lung cancer that has spread to only one other part of the body outside of the chest may be treated with surgery, radiation or both. When lung cancer spreads outside of the chest area, it usually spreads to more than one location, in these cases, treatment depends on features of the tumor cells called mutations and biomarkers.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for stage IV non-small cell lung cancer? (2)
Response.Content:
Although it is rare, lung cancer that has spread to only one other part of the body outside of the chest may be treated with surgery, radiation or both. When lung cancer spreads outside of the chest area, it usually spreads to more than one location, in these cases, treatment depends on features of the tumor cells called mutations and biomarkers.
Supportive care is an important component of treatment at this stage. Studies have shown that patients with metastatic lung cancer live longer and have better quality of life when receiving supportive or palliative care than they do when they are receiving aggressive medical treatments such as chemotherapy and radiation. Discuss supportive care options with your care team and make sure they understand your treatment goals.

Response.BaseQuestion: Deleted
Response.Content: Stage I small cell lung cancer is a small tumor that has not spread to any lymph nodes and can be completely removed by a surgeon. Doctors may use the letters "A" and "B" to describe how large the tumor is. Tumors less than 3 cm wide are called stage IA. Tumors between 3 and 5 cm wide are stage IB.

Response.BaseQuestion: Deleted
Response.Content:
There are two types of stage two lung cancers.
Stage 2A tumors are between 5 and 7 cm wide and have not spread to nearby lymph nodes. Stage 2A also describes a smaller tumor, less than 5 cm wide, when there are signs that the cancer has spread to the nearby lymph nodes.
Stage 2B describes tumors between 5 and 7 cm that have spread to nearby lymph nodes, or a tumor between 5-7 cm wide that may have grown into other nearby parts of the lung, but has not spread to nearby lymph nodes. Sometimes these tumors can be removed by surgeons, but patients may also need additional treatments such as chemotherapy or radiation.

Response.BaseQuestion: What can I do if I have mouth sores from mucositis?
Response.Content:
Treatment for mucositis involves keeping the mouth moisturized, preventing infection, and managing pain. Some easy remedies include chewing ice chips, chewing sugarless gum, or sucking tart sugar free candy.
There are also over-the-counter products that can help with dry mouth, and if necessary, your doctor can prescribe one for you as well.
You can use a soft bristle toothbrush to every 4 hours and at bedtime. It is important to brush and floss very gently to avoid additional damage. Rinse your mouth frequently with antiseptic mouth rinses, such as Peridex or Periogard, to prevent infections and inflammation.
Your doctor may need to prescribe other medications to treat infections in your mouth. Pain from mucositis can prevent you from getting enough nutrition as eating and swallowing become difficult. If pain is mild, using ice chips or pops can help. If pain is worse, oral pain relief gels or lozenges may be used. Your doctor can also prescribe additional medications to help with pain from mucositis.

Response.BaseQuestion: Deleted
Response.Content: Stage IIIB describes tumors that have grown into the heart or other nearby parts of the body, and have also spread to lymph nodes in the chest or lung. Stage IIIB also refers to tumors that have spread to the lymph nodes located above the collar bone and measure more than 7 cm wide, or are located in the main airway, or have grown into the heart or diaphragm or other major parts of the body.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is cryotherapy?
Response.Content:
Cryotherapy kills cancer cells by freezing them. It is also called cryosurgery or cryoablation.
Cryotherapy is used if a tumor is blocking an airway and traditional surgery is not an option.
Cryotherapy is done in a clinic or outpatient area of a hospital, meaning that you can usually return home after surgery.
Before the procedure you will get medicine through a small tube put into a vein in your hand to make you fall asleep. During the procedure, your doctor will put a long, thin, flexible tube called a bronchoscope down your throat and into the airway. A special tool is then put through the bronchoscope tube. This tool freezes one section of the tumor at a time until they have treated the whole area. Then doctors remove the tissue through the bronchoscope tube. This normally takes about 30 minutes.
Once you are fully awake and recovered from the procedure, you should be able to go home, and to eat and drink normally.
After surgery, your throat and chest may be a bit sore for a few days, but you should be able to breath more easily than before. You may also cough up tissue or see a small amount of blood in your saliva for a few days after cryotherapy. But, if you are coughing up blood, or having more difficulty breathing, let your health care team know immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Small cell lung cancer begins in the nerve cells or hormone-producing cells of the lungs. The description "small cell" refers to the size and shape of these types of cells. About 10% to 15% of lung cancers are small cell lung cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Question 005 What type of small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Have you been told what stage of small cell lung cancer you have?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the stages of small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Small cell lung cancer is described as limited stage or extensive stage.
Limited stage means that the cancer is only in one side of the chest and may involve lymph nodes close to the lung.
Extensive stage describes small cell lung cancer that has spread to the other lung or to other parts of the body.
These descriptions help doctors determine what treatment will be best for you.

Response.BaseQuestion: Question X What stage SCLC
Response.Content: Have you been told what stage of small cell lung cancer you have?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is limited stage small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Limited small cell lung cancer means that the cancer is only in one side of your chest and involves only lymph nodes close to the lung. Doctors consider limited small cell lung cancer to be stages 0-3.
This type of small cell lung cancer is usually treated with radiation therapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is limited stage small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Limited small cell lung cancer means that the cancer is only in one side of your chest and involves only lymph nodes close to the lung. Doctors consider limited small cell lung cancer to be stages 0-3.
This type of small cell lung cancer is usually treated with radiation therapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is extensive stage small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Extensive stage small cell lung cancer describes cancer that has spread and is found in more than one location in your lungs or in other parts of your body such as bone, brain or bone marrow.
This is also considered stage IV small cell lung cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is extensive stage small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
Extensive stage small cell lung cancer describes cancer that has spread and is found in more than one location in your lungs or in other parts of your body such as bone, brain or bone marrow.
This is also considered stage IV small cell lung cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Answer to question 006 Don't know what type of SCLC.
Response.Content:
If you're not sure what type of small cell lung cancer you have, we'll just go over the basics.
Make sure to talk to your doctor at your next appointment, then you can update your personal profile with this information the next time you log in.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment for limited stage small cell lung cancer(1)
Response.Content:
Before treatment for limited stage small cell lung cancer, tests will be done to determine where it has spread and how best to treat it. If there is a buildup of too much fluid the space that surrounds the lungs, doctors may do a Thoracentesis or Thoracoscopy.
Thoracentesis involves using a needle to withdraw fluid from the chest area around the lungs or heart. The fluid is then looked at under a microscope to see there are cancer cells in it.
In thoracoscopy the thin, flexible tube, called a thoracoscope, is inserted through a small incision in the chest. A very small camera on the thoracoscope allows the surgeon to see the lungs, the area between the lungs called the mediastinum, and the membrane covering the lungs and the lining of the chest cavity, called the pleura.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment for limited stage SCLC (2)
Response.Content:
For some patients, doctors may also order pulmonary function tests, X-rays or MRI scans and a bone marrow biopsy.
Depending on what your doctor finds during these tests, you may need to have a procedure called a mediastinoscopy to get samples of tissue from the lymph nodes located between the lungs. These lymph nodes will give your doctor a better idea of whether and how far your cancer has spread. Your diagnosis may change to a different stage and this may affect the type of treatment that your doctor recommends.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is limited stage small cell lung cancer treated?
Response.Content:
If there is no evidence that your cancer has spread to the mediastinal lymph nodes in the center of your chest, you may have surgery to remove the tumor and lymph nodes. Following surgery, you will have either chemotherapy alone or chemoradiation.
If your doctor believes you are not a good candidate for surgery, or if tests show that the cancer has spread to the mediastinal lymph nodes, you will be treated with either chemotherapy alone, or chemoradiation therapy.
Some people with small cell lung cancer are too sick to be treated with either chemotherapy or radiation. In these cases, the patient's symptoms are given palliative treatment with comfort being the main treatment goal.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is extensive stage small cell lung cancer treated?
Response.Content:
Treatment for extensive stage small cell lung cancer depends on your performance status, which is a measure of how well you are able to care for yourself, your daily activity levels, and whether you're able to do physical tasks such as walking.
Treatment also depends on whether the cancer has spread to your brain. Supportive care is an important component of treatment at this stage. Studies have shown that patients with metastatic lung cancer live longer and have better quality of life when receiving supportive or palliative care than they do when they are receiving aggressive medical treatments such as chemotherapy and radiation.
Discuss supportive care options with your care team and make sure they understand your treatment goals.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is extensive stage small cell lung cancer treated? (2)
Response.Content: If your performance status is good, and your cancer is not causing pain or difficulty breathing, is not pressing on major blood vessels and has not spread to the brain or bone, your treatment will include chemotherapy and any other treatments needed to control symptoms and make you comfortable.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is extensive stage small cell lung cancer treated? (3)
Response.Content:
If your cancer is causing pain or difficulty breathing, or is pressing on your airways, major blood vessels or spinal cord, and has spread to the bone, your treatment will include chemotherapy and radiation and any other treatments needed to control pain and other symptoms and make you comfortable.
Treatment with bisphosphonates is given to help strengthen your bones.
Doctors may also recommend radiation therapy to the brain in order to prevent the spread of cancer, this is called prophylactic cranial radiotherapy or PCRT.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is extensive stage small cell lung cancer treated? (4)
Response.Content:
If lung cancer has spread to the brain, and you are not having any symptoms of brain metastases, your treatment will include chemotherapy followed by whole brain radiation.
If you are having symptoms of brain metastases such as changes in memory, attention, or thinking, behavior changes, unsteadiness, changes in your vision, difficulty finding words, headache, weakness, or seizures, you may have whole brain radiation therapy before chemotherapy.
You will also have any other treatments needed to control pain and other symptoms and make you comfortable.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is extensive stage small cell lung cancer treated? (5)
Response.Content: If your performance status is not good for reasons other than your cancer and your doctor believes that cancer treatment will make you worse off, you will be given the care needed to control symptoms and make you comfortable.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is extensive stage small cell lung cancer monitored after treatment?
Response.Content: After your initial therapy, doctors will monitor you by doing a complete blood count or CBC, and doctors will also want to check your electrolytes, liver function, calcium levels, your lactic acid dehydrogenase or LDH level, and your blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinin levels. Scans can help determine whether your cancer has spread to other areas so your doctor will order chest/liver/adrenal CTs with contrast, a Brain MRI or CT with contrast.

Response.BaseQuestion: Testing before treatment of extensive stage small cell lung cancer
Response.Content:
When making a diagnosis of extensive stage small cell lung cancer, your doctor will need to do some more tests to find out how advanced your cancer is.
Usually the doctor will take a medical history and perform a physical exam. She may order a biopsy and have a pathologist look at the tissue sample.
You will need to have blood drawn for a complete blood count or CBC, and doctors will also want to check your electrolytes, liver function, calcium levels, your lactic acid dehydrogenase or LDH level, and your blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinin levels.
Scans can help determine whether your cancer has spread to other areas so your doctor will order chest/liver/adrenal CTs with contrast, a Brain MRI or CT with contrast, or a PET/CT if limited stage is suspected.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the different types of lung cancer?
Response.Content:
The two most common types of lung cancer are non-small cell lung cancer and small cell lung cancer.
About 80 percent of lung cancers are non-small cell cancer. These types describe the type of cancer cells that make up the tumor. The second most common type is small cell lung cancer.
10% to 15% of lung cancers are small cell lung cancer.
There are other very rare types of lung cancer called carcinoids which includes adenoid cystic carcinomas, lymphomas, and sarcomas, as well as benign lung tumors such as hamartomas. Carcinoids are slow growing and are usually treated with surgery.
This program focuses on non-small cell lung cancer and small cell lung cancer because they are the most common. You can find links to information on these and other more rare types of lung cancer in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for extensive stage small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content: Depending on the stage of small cell lung cancer, your level of functioning, and whether and where your cancer has spread, your treatment may include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and other treatments to relieve symptoms and help you feel more comfortable.

Response.BaseQuestion: Where does lung cancer usually spread?
Response.Content: Metastases can form in any area of the body, but with lung cancer the most common sites for metastases are the bone, brain, liver, kidney, adrenal glands and in some cases the lymph nodes. Depending on where your metastases are, your symptoms and treatment may be different.

Response.BaseQuestion: Where does lung cancer usually spread? (2)
Response.Content: Lung cancer often spreads to the lymph nodes before spreading to other areas of the body. The lymph nodes between the lungs are often the first place that lung cancer spreads to. You may have a sentinel node biopsy to find out whether these lymph nodes contain cancer cells. In stages I-III, surgery to remove some or all of the lymph nodes is recommended.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are brain metastases?
Response.Content:
Brain metastases mean that your original cancer has spread to the brain. If your doctor suspects that your cancer has spread to your brain, your care team will do additional tests such as an MRI or CT scan. A biopsy may also be needed.
Symptoms of brain metastases include headaches, speech difficulties, seizures, nausea and vomiting, weakness of an arm or leg, or problems with your eyesight If brain metastases are causing seizures, you may be given an anti-seizure medicine. Corticosteroids, often just called steroids, are used to reduce swelling and may make many of your symptoms go away quickly. But this does not mean that the tumor is gone.
Because most chemotherapy drugs are not able to enter the brain, treatment of brain metastases is usually radiation therapy or surgery.If you have a single brain lesion that is in part of the brain where it is safe to operate, surgery may be recommended. Surgery for brain metastases may be done by opening your skull and removing the tumor, or it may be done using pinpoint radiation therapy called Stereotactic Radiosurgery.
If surgery is not an option, whole brain radiotherapy may be used to shrink tumors and keep them from growing. In most cases, once cancer spreads to the brain, the cancer is not curable, but it can be treated to reduce the side effects. With current treatments, patients can live from months to years, depending on the number of brain metastases, the type of tumor, and the amount of cancer present in the rest of the body.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is liver metastases?
Response.Content:
The liver is a common site for metastases because it gets lots of blood and provides a welcome environment for cancer cells to grow.
Signs of liver metastases include vomiting more than twice a day for more than one day, having blood in your vomit, weight loss, black bowel movements, difficulty swallowing, new swelling in the legs or abdomen and jaundice or yellowing of the skin. Your liver may also feel enlarged or misshapen when the doctor examines you, and you may have pain in the upper right part of your stomach.
If your doctor thinks your cancer may have spread to your liver, you may need to have a liver function test. Various scans such as a CT scan, ultrasound or MRI might be done on your liver. An angiogram or laparoscopy may also be done.
Drug therapy, usually chemotherapy, is used to treat most cases of lung cancer that has spread to your liver. Chemotherapy may be given through an IV if there are metastases in other locations as well as the liver. Or, chemotherapy can be injected directly into the liver.
Radiofrequency Ablation and Microwave ablation may be done to shrink tumors. Embolization is also used to shrink liver metastases by reducing the blood supply that the tumor needs to grow.
Surgery is usually only done if there are only a few areas affected by tumors. Chemotherapy may be used after surgery as well.
How well patients do depends on the location of the original cancer and how much it has spread to the liver. In most cases, cancer that has spread to the liver is not curable. However, treatment may help shrink tumors, improve life expectancy, and relieve symptoms. In a small number of cases, surgery to remove the liver tumors may lead to a cure.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is adrenal gland metastases?
Response.Content:
Adrenal glands are small glands that sit on top of the kidneys. They produce hormones, including cortisol, epinephrine, commonly called adrenaline, and norepinephrine. Up to 40 percent of people with lung cancer will develop adrenal metastases.
Symptoms of adrenal gland metastases include back pain, abdominal pain, and bleeding into the abdomen. Another sign of metastases to these glands is adrenal insufficiency, also called Addison's disease, which is a group of symptoms including weakness, low blood pressure, low blood sugar, and low sodium and high potassium in the blood.
If your doctor thinks your cancer might have spread to your adrenal glands, you may be sent for a scan such as a CT or MRI. In some cases, a CT-guided biopsy will be done to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment of adrenal gland metastases includes chemotherapy, targeted therapies or radiation therapy. Surgery to remove one or both of the adrenal glands may be done, especially if the tumor is bleeding or at risk of bleeding. Stereotactic body radiotherapy may be another option if surgery is not advised. If the metastasis has resulted in adrenal insufficiency, treatment with steroids may be needed.
The prognosis for adrenal metastases from lung cancer may be better than the prognosis of other metastases - such as those to the liver, brain, and bones.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are bone metastases?
Response.Content: Bone metastases can cause severe pain, and bone fractures. They can also cause levels of minerals and vitamins in your body, called electrolytes, to become out of balance, which can be life-threatening. Bone metastases can also press on nerves which can cause pain, weakness, or numbness and tingling sensation in the feet and legs. Nerve compression may also cause problems with bowel and bladder function. This may result in incontinence, meaning that you cannot control your urine or bowel movements; or in constipation or urinary retention, meaning that it is difficult to urinate or have a bowel movement. If the metastases are pressing on the spinal cord, you may have weakness in your legs and find it hard to move them. Spinal cord compression is an emergency and you should get immediate medical attention. A less common symptom of bone metastasis is high levels of calcium in the body. High calcium can cause constipation, and abdominal pain. If calcium levels are very high, it can affect the brain, causing you to become confused and have problems thinking clearly. This is also an emergency and you should report any of these symptoms to your doctor.

Response.BaseQuestion: How are bone metastases treated?
Response.Content: The best treatment for bone metastasis is the treatment of the original cancer. Therapies may include chemotherapy, hormone therapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, or treatment with monoclonal antibodies. Pain is often treated with narcotics and other pain medications, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs called NSAIDs. Make sure you talk to your doctor before taking any over the counter medications.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are bisphosphonates?
Response.Content: Bisphosphonates are medications that decrease pain from bone metastasis and help make bones stronger. Bisphosphonates are a man-made version of pyrophosphate, which is something that your body makes naturally that prevents bone breakdown. Usually bisphosphonates are given through an IV infusion. The side effects are fairly mild and include a flu-like reaction during the first 48 hours after having the IV infusion, nausea, and low calcium levels. More serious side effects with long-term use may include kidney damage, and damage to the bones in your jaw. Patients with kidney problems may not be able to use bisphosphonates.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the EGFR or Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor mutation?
Response.Content: EGFR stands for Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor. This is a feature of some lung cancer cells that allows cancer cells to grow uncontrollably. There are some medications, called targeted therapies, that can turn off the epidermal growth factor receptors and slow or stop tumor growth. These medications are the preferred treatment for stage IV cancer with the EGFR mutation.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are mutations?
Response.Content: Mutations are changes in your genes, parts of your cells that tell the cell how and when to grow and divide. These changes can be harmless, or they can cause the cells to grown and divide uncontrollably, which results in cancer. There are a number of different mutations that drive lung cancer growth and your doctor may test for these mutations so that your treatment can be targeted to the specific mutation. Common mutations include ALK, EGFR, ROS1 and PD-L1.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the ALK rearrangement mutations?
Response.Content:
ALK rearrangement mutations affect the anaplastic lymphoma kinase or ALK gene. In these mutations, the genes become rearranged and joined with another gene. This causes cancer cells to grow and spread faster than normal cells. Tumors with the ALK mutations are treated with targeted medications called tyrosine kinase inhibitors or TKIs.
Two TKIs used to treat non-small cell lung cancer with the ALK mutation are Crizotinib (Xalkori) or ceritinib (Zykadia). Generally, these medications are given as a pill that you take by the mouth. As with any treatments, these medications have side effects than can be serious. For more information on TKIs, look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the PD-L1 mutation?
Response.Content:
Normally, our immune system helps to prevent illnesses, but in cancers with the PD-L1 mutation, the cancer cells have extra proteins that trick the immune system into thinking they are normal cells. Monoclonal antibodies are immunotherapy drugs that block the extra proteins and help the immune system destroy the cancer cells.
Some common mono-clonal antibody drugs are Pembro-liz-u-mab, brand name Keytruda, Nivolumab brand name Opdivo, Atizolizumab brand name Tecentriq and Avelumab, brand name Bavencio. Generally, these medications are given as a pill that you take by the mouth. As with any treatments, these medications have side effects which can be serious.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the ROS1 mutation?
Response.Content: The ROS1 mutation is also known as ROS, MCF3, and c-ros. This mutation fuses with genes that change the normal signal patterns of the immune system that help protect cells. Tumors with ROS1 mutations are usually treated with immunotherapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is cancer with the EFGR mutation treated?
Response.Content: The drugs that treat cancer with EFGR mutations are called tyrosine kinase inhibitors or TKIs. Examples of TKIs are erlotinib (Tarceva) and gefitinib (Iressa). Generally, these medications are given as a pill that you take by mouth. As with any treatments, these medications have side effects than can be serious. For more information on TKIs, look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is cancer with the EGFR mutation treated? (2)
Response.Content: If the EGFR mutation is discovered before you start chemotherapy, your doctor may start your treatment with immunotherapy. If it is discovered during chemotherapy treatment, your doctor may complete your planned chemotherapy course or your chemotherapy may be interrupted to start immunotherapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: Treatment with targeted therapies (2)
Response.Content: You may also receive chemotherapy, chemoradiation or radiation therapy in addition to the targeted therapies that treat the specific mutations of your cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the treatment for AKL mutation (2)
Response.Content: If the ALK mutation is discovered before you start chemotherapy, your doctor may start your treatment with immunotherapy. If it is discovered during chemotherapy treatment, your doctor may complete your planned chemotherapy course or your chemotherapy may be interrupted to start immunotherapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I participate in my cancer care?
Response.Content: One of the most important things you have to do on your cancer journey is take an active role in managing your illness. Here's what that means: If you have questions -- ask your doctor. They want you to be well informed so that you can make treatment decisions that are right for you. Taking an active role also means keeping your treatment appointments and taking your medication how and when you're supposed to. You don't want to skip appointments or doses of your medications because your treatments might not be as effective. You also need to report symptoms and side effects so that they don't get in the way of your treatments. Discuss even mild side effects with your health care team because some side effects may become serious and delay or stop you from getting all of your cancer treatments. Try to eat a healthy diet and stay as physically active as you are able to, although it may be challenging if you're feeling tired and you've lost your appetite. Many of our patients find that being physically active actually increases their energy. Quitting smoking will also be beneficial to your treatment and your doctor can help support you if you decide to quit. Ask your doctor what other changes you can make to support your treatment. And remember, the decisions on what treatments are best for you are yours, not your family's or other caregivers'. You and your doctor know what is best given your treatment goals.

Response.BaseQuestion: What do I need to know about undergoing cancer treatment?
Response.Content: So, before we start talking about specific medical treatments, I want to talk to you a little bit about what it's like to be treated for cancer, no matter what type or stage of cancer you have. We've heard from many people with cancer and their caregivers, that they didn't understand the demands that their cancer treatment would place on them and their loved ones. Depending on your specific treatment plan, you may need to get treatment several times a week, even daily. And, you may have to get frequent blood work, scans and other tests. You may find that you need help with transportation and keeping track of your medications, appointments and all paperwork as well. So, when discussing treatment with your doctor, make sure you find out how often and how long you will need to be at the treatment center, what kinds of tests will be done and how often they will be needed. It's important to ask your care team about this and what side effects are common with your treatment. Side effects, such as fatigue and nausea, can make it difficult to keep working, or even to do everyday tasks.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I have side effects?
Response.Content: Most patients will have some side effects from their cancer treatments. The severity of side effects varies from treatment to treatment and person to person, and side effects can have a big impact on your lifestyle and your outlook, especially if they are severe. Many side effects can be successfully treated, so it is important to talk to your oncology nurse as soon as you begin experiencing any side effects. I want to stress to you that if you do experience side effects, do skip your cancer treatments or stop taking your medication exactly as instructed unless your healthcare provider tells you to. If some side effects become too severe, it may cause a delay or change to your treatment. Another reason to report side effects quickly is that some side effects, if not treated early, can become quite serious, even life threatening. Do not take any physical symptoms you may have lightly. If you have chest pain or trouble breathing call 911 immediately. No matter what treatment you're getting, you need to call your oncologists office. If the you have any of these symptoms: #8226 A temperature over 100.4. #8226 Stomach swelling, tenderness, or pain #8226; Dark urine #8226 Bloody or dark stool #8226 Moderate to severe pain or cramps #8226 or Nausea or vomiting despite taking anti-nausea medications. Remember that AHN's After Hours Oncology Clinic is available from 3 pm until 9pm weekdays. For information on the After Hours Clinic, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are any of the side effects serious?
Response.Content: There are some side effects of cancer and cancer treatments that are common no matter how your cancer is being treated. It's important to be aware of some these side effects because they can be serious and can affect your treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is shortness of breath?
Response.Content: Shortness of breath, called dyspnea, is common for people with lung cancer. Breathing can be uncomfortable and you may feel like you can't get enough air into your lungs. It is important to tell your doctor if you are having difficulty breathing so he or she can determine the cause. Shortness of breath can be caused by a tumor in or near an airway, inflammation in the lung from radiation treatments, fluid buildup around the lungs, called pleural effusion, or the heart, called pericardial effusion. Stress and anxiety may cause you to feel like you can't breathe, too. No matter what the cause, shortness of breath can be a frightening experience. Manage anxiety by taking slow, steady, deep breaths, and try to visualize a setting that relaxes and calms you. Try to stay focused on the setting and breathe slowly. There are things you can do to prevent or reduce the times that you feel short of breath. First of all, if you smoke, try to quit. Your health care provider can help you stop smoking with medication if necessary. And, avoid smoky places. Try to stay healthy. Wash your hands frequently, and stay clear of people who are sick to avoid getting infections. Talk to your doctor about whether using an incentive spirometer, which is a device designed to improve lung function, might help improve your breathing. Drink lots of liquids to stay hydrated. This can help thin mucus and make coughing easier. Using a humidifier or a vaporizer may help thin mucus and make coughing easier, too. Try light exercise, if possible. Exercise can help increase the flow of oxygen to your blood. Sleeping with your head raised on pillows may make it easier to breathe at night. Talk to your doctor about whether seeing a respiratory therapist or getting supplemental oxygen would be helpful. There is information on support for quitting smoking in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is fatigue?
Response.Content: Fatigue is one of the most common symptoms experienced by people with cancer. Most patients describe this as much more than just feeling tired. It is a feeling of complete exhaustion where even the smallest effort seems impossible. Usually, it comes on suddenly and is not the result of activity or strain, and is not relieved by rest or sleep. Fatigue can be can be caused by many things, so it is important to tell your health care team if you notice a change in your energy level.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are sleep problems?
Response.Content: Sleep problems are reported by up to 90 percent of patients with cancer. Some people find it difficult to sleep because they are in pain or they have restless legs syndrome (RLS) which can be caused by some cancer treatments. Often times, cancer drugs cause people to feel tired and sleepy throughout the day. They end up napping or sleeping during the day and that leads to difficulty sleeping at night. Sometimes sleep problems are caused by medications prescribed to combat side effects of the chemotherapy. Stress and tension about your diagnosis and treatment can also cause sleep problems. It is important to report any sleep issues to your doctor. Sleep is important for people with cancer -- it restores the energy you need to fight your cancer, and is essential for reducing anxiety and depression. Stress actually weakens your body's immune system. Lack of sleep can also impact levels of hormones that affect how cancer cells behave. Talk to your doctor or oncology nurse about sleep problems, there are a number of things you can do to improve sleep: • Do not eat or exercise within 2 hours of bedtime • Make your room dark. • Use the bed only for sleeping, not for watching TV or reading • Keep a consistent sleep schedule. Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day • Make sure you are taking your medications at the right time of day • And cut down on caffeine and avoid drinking caffeine in the evening. • If you are still having problems sleeping try keeping a sleep diary to show to your doctor. Depending on the reasons you are having trouble sleeping, your health care provider may prescribe medication to help you sleep better.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I have pain?
Response.Content: Lung cancer patients may experience pain from many different sources, whether from tumors in the lungs, metastases to other parts of the body, or from cancer treatments themselves. Make sure to tell your cancer treatment team about any pain you are having. It is important to stay on top of your pain and follow the directions for any pain medications your doctor gives you. It is easier to treat pain if you stick to a medication schedule and do not skip doses. Opioids are commonly prescribed to ease cancer pain. These are strong medications that block pain signals in the brain. Other medications may be used along with them. These pain killers can cause side effects of their own, including constipation, so alert your doctor to any changes in your health.

Response.BaseQuestion: How will cancer affect me emotionally?
Response.Content: Having cancer doesn't just affect your physical health. Even the possibility of a cancer diagnosis can cause fear, anxiety, depression and even guilt. These emotions are normal, but you should not ignore them. Taking care of your emotional well-being is as important as taking care of your physical health.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does cancer cause depression?
Response.Content: A cancer diagnosis may cause anyone to feel sad or down, but when that sadness persists and affects your usual activities you may be depressed. Depression can also be a side effect of many cancer drugs. It could be a sign that your cancer medication or treatment needs to be adjusted. Do not wait to contact your health care team if you think you may be depressed. If un-treated, depression only gets worse. The sooner you let your health care team know how you are feeling, the sooner you can find relief. Your doctor may prescribe anti-depressants. Remember it can take up to two weeks for anti-depressant medication to begin working. You may also be referred to a counselor to help you find ways to cope with your situation. Getting professional help for depression is just as important as taking your medications. Check the Resource Area for more on the symptoms and treatment of depression.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I deal with anxiety?
Response.Content: It is not unusual to experience some anxiety when you are diagnosed with cancer and at different times during treatment. If your anxiety interferes with your normal activities or relationships, you need to let your health care team know about it. There are medications that may help and referrals for other types of therapies have been shown to be effective. Some symptoms of anxiety are: • Excessive worry about events or activities • Muscle tension • Sleep changes- either being unable to sleep or sleeping more than usual • Physical symptoms such as rapid heartbeat, sweating, palpitations, trembling, shortness of breath, chest tightness, nausea, diarrhea, flushing, dizziness, or high blood pressure. • Exhaustion • Difficulty concentrating • And irritability or restlessness. Activities that may help relieve anxiety are: • Progressive muscle relaxation exercises • Meditation • Yoga • Listening to music or participating in Music Therapy • Massage • Engaging in your usual spiritual activities • And physical activity.
