Response.BaseQuestion: Answer to question 008 I want information on my prognosis
Response.Content:
Alright, you want to know as much information as possible about what your prognosis is. But first, there are a few things I want you to remember when learning about your prognosis.
Doctors often use the 5-year survival rate when talking about prog-no-sees. This is the percentage of people with a specific type and stage of cancer that are alive at least 5 years after their cancer diagnosis. But many people live longer -- often much longer -- than 5 years.
For example, a 5-year survival rate of 50% means that an estimated 50 out of 100 people who have that cancer are still alive 5 years after being diagnosed. And many of those people have many years yet to go.
These numbers can't tell you how long you will live, but they may help give you a better understanding about how likely it is that your treatment will be useful.
Keep in mind as you hear this information that statistics are estimates, educated guesses that describe trends in large numbers of people. These statistics do not necessarily predict what will actually happen to you.

Response.BaseQuestion: What do I need to know about prognosis statistics?
Response.Content: Before we get into the specific prognosis for your type of cancer, there are a few things I need to tell you. First, keep in mind that there have been many advances in treatments since these statistics were calculated, and that people who are now being diagnosed with lung cancer may have a better outlook than someone diagnosed five years ago. Also, these statistics are based on the stage of the cancer when it was first diagnosed. They do not apply to cancers that later come back or spread. And lastly, remember that many factors can affect your prognosis, such as the type of cancer, gene changes in the cancer cells, your age, overall health and performance status, other health conditions you may have, and how well your cancer responds to treatment.

Response.Content:
Extensive stage, or stage IV small cell lung cancer has a five year survival rate of 2%. This means that out of every 100 patients with extensive small cell lung cancer, 2 survived for a minimum of 5 years following their diagnosis.
Survival rates are only estimates, and much of the disease course is dependent on individual factors specific to the patient and their cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: DO NOT USE What is the survival rate for extensive (stages II-IV) small cell lung cancer?
Response.Content:
DO NOT USE The median survival time for extensive stage small cell lung cancer is 4.5 months. Survival time depends upon the type of metastases. Median survival time of patients with brain metastases was 9 months while median survival time of patients with metastases in other locations at primary diagnosis was 11 months.
With treatment, for stage II small cell lung cancer, the 5-year relative survival rate is about 19% which means that out of every 100 patients with extensive stage small cell lung cancer, 19 individuals lived for a minimum of 5 years after their diagnosis.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is NSCLC Staged?
Response.Content: There are a number of procedures and tests that are used to determine the stage of non-small cell lung cancer. Your doctor may recommend more scans such as CT scans with or without contrast, PET or MRI scans. These types of tests can help determine the clinical stage of cancer. Surgery and biopsies that remove tissue that the pathologist examines under the microscope determines the pathological stage of the cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What to expect from cancer treatment?
Response.Content: We've talked many people with cancer and their caregivers, and what they tell us is that they weren't prepared for how cancer treatment affected every area of their life. Depending on your specific treatment plan, you may need to get treatment several times a week, and you may have to get frequent blood work, scans and other tests. You may find that you need help with transportation and keeping track of the paperwork, medications and appointments as well. The side effects can make it difficult to keep working, or even to do every day tasks. So, when discussing treatment with your doctor, make sure you find out how often you will need to go into the treatment center, what kinds of tests will be done and how often they will be needed. Another important topic to ask your doctor about is what side effects you can expect from your treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens after treatment for Stage I NSCLC?
Response.Content: After your treatments are finished you will be watched with a physical exam and chest CT with contrast every 3 to 6 months for 3 years, then every 6 months for 2 years. After that you will get a low dose computed topography (LDCT) scan with no contrast or a chest CT yearly. If there are any nodules that your doctor thinks should be monitored more closely, or if anything unusual shows on examination or your scans, your doctor may recommend more frequent tests.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens after treatment for Stage II NSCLC?
Response.Content: After your treatments are finished you will be watched with a physical exam and chest CT with contrast every 3 to 6 months for 3 years, then every 6 months for 2 years. After that you will get a low dose computed topography (LDCT) scan with no contrast or a chest CT yearly. If there are any nodules that your doctor thinks should be monitored more closely, or if anything unusual shows on examination or your scans, your doctor may recommend more frequent tests.

Response.BaseQuestion: Segue to treatments
Response.Content: Remember that many factors can affect your prognosis, such as the type of cancer, gene changes in the cancer cells, your age and overall health, and how well your cancer responds to treatment. No matter what your prognosis, there are things you can do now to manage your illness and prepare for treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: Question 008 What is your role as caregiver? (Do not use)
Response.Content: Tell me more about your role as caregiver. Do you live with your loved one, close by, or are you far away?

Response.BaseQuestion: How can caregivers help their loved ones organize information?
Response.Content: One of the main roles that caregivers fill is that of organizer. As with every serious illness, there will be a lot of information to keep track of. Depending on your loved one abilities, this role may start off small, then grow more important and time consuming. It is a good idea to keep a journal that contains the phone numbers of your loved one's health care team and others who provide support such as neighbors,other friends and family and community services. Make sure you get the after-hours numbers for doctors so that you can reach a member of the health care team at any time. This journal can also be used to track information about appointments, including which health care provider was seen and what they said. All medications that your loved one takes should be tracked in the journal as well, including any vitamins or other supplements, eye drops, medication patches, and over-the-counter medications. Keep track of the dose, when and how often it is taken, and any other instructions such as whether a medication should be taken with or without food.

Response.BaseQuestion: How else can I support my loved one?
Response.Content: Other roles that you may fill as caregiver depend on what your loved one needs. It is a good idea to find out what your loved one is capable of doing, and how much support they want. Then you can be clear about what is expected of you, how much you will be doing, and what you can get others to help with. There is a list of tasks in the Resources area that can help get you started. You will want to go over the list you make when there are changes in your loved one's condition. Be sure to include your loved one in these discussions as much as you can. Maintaining as much independence as possible and having a say in their care helps people with cancer feel more in control of their situation.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I care for my loved one if I live far away?
Response.Content: Many people are long distance caregivers and even though you aren't close by, you can play a very important role in the care of your loved one. You can coordinate care over the phone or email, follow up on insurance and other financial information, do research, and keep other friends and family informed about your loved one's condition and needs. Your emotional support is key as well, for both your loved one and other caregivers.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I help my loved one with financial issues and insurance?
Response.Content: Financial concerns are often a main source of stress for people with cancer and their loved ones. Even if your loved one has health insurance, treatment costs can add up. Understanding what is covered by insurance, and what co-pays and out-of-pocket expenses will be is very important so that these costs can be tracked. If your loved one has insurance, have them give the insurance company permission to talk with you about their coverage. Ask the insurance company if they have case managers for people with serious illnesses so that you can talk with the same person each time you call. When you do talk with the insurance company, take notes of each conversation. Note who you spoke with, the date and time, and what was said.

Response.BaseQuestion: What information do I need to keep track of for my loved one?
Response.Content: There is a lot of paperwork that comes with a serious illness so it's a good idea to organize this information from the start. You will need to keep all medical bills, insurance company paper work, and receipts from the pharmacy and copays. Extra expenses like parking, transportation costs, and anything else related to your loved one's cancer care should be tracked as well. Keep all receipts and mark them with the date of service. These expenses may be deductible from your loved one's taxes.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who can help us with financial issues?
Response.Content: Even people with insurance can struggle to pay for their care. There are sources of financial help available. Talk with the hospital social worker or case manager to discuss treatment costs, they may be able to connect you with resources to help. Also, many pharmaceutical companies have programs that help cover the cost of cancer treatments.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I help my loved one who can't make treatment decisions?
Response.Content: You can help by making sure that your loved one fully understands the risks and benefits of each treatment. Make sure that you understand your loved one's wishes when it comes to treatment goals, and make sure that others are respecting these wishes as well.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if my loved one can't make their own health care decisions?
Response.Content: At some point, your loved one may not be able to make decisions about their care and will need someone to make those decisions for them. A health care proxy or medical power-of-attorney is a person that is chosen by your loved one to make these decisions for them. Discuss appointing a health care proxy with your loved one. In the Resources area, you'll find a list to help you decide who would be the best person to take on this role

Response.BaseQuestion: How I prepare to make health care decisions for my loved one?
Response.Content: There may come a time when you or your loved one must make very difficult decisions about their treatment. Discuss your loved one's wishes and goals of treatment openly and make sure that other family and caregivers as well as their health care team is aware of them. Help your loved one to document their wishes in a living will. There are links to information on living wills in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I help my loved one take their medications safely at home?
Response.Content: Even though many cancer treatments are given in a hospital or clinic setting, there may be a number of medications that your loved one need to take at home. It is important that your loved one take all of their medications exactly as their doctor has instructed, and this is another area where you can be of great help. It can be difficult to understand the complex instructions for each medication, so you can help your loved one by keeping track of their medications and all of the instructions that go along with them. Some people find that a written schedule or list of medications is helpful. Make sure to include all medications that your loved one is taking, including creams, patches, eye drops, and over-the-counter medications and supplements. It can also be helpful to keep track of when a medication is taken so that doses aren't skipped or doubled accidently.

Response.BaseQuestion: What precautions should I take with oral oncology medications?
Response.Content: There are now some chemotherapy and other cancer medications that are taken by mouth rather than by IV and these medications can be taken at home. They are just as powerful as the treatments given in cancer treatment clinics, so caregivers and other family members must be careful not to touch these medications. Also, make sure you take these special precautions to stay safe when handling body fluids from people who are taking cancer medications: • If you are helping someone take their medication at home, wear disposable gloves and throw them in the regular household trash when done. Used gloves should not be re-used for anything else. • Keep all drugs out of reach of children and pets. • Pregnant caregivers should not handle oral cancer drugs • Cancer drugs should remain in their original packaging until used • Do not let the medication come in contact with household surfaces like countertops or tables, and if they do, clean the surface thoroughly afterwards to prevent others from coming into contact with traces of the medication. • When giving someone their medication, put the pill into a medication cup. Then they can tip the cup to their mouth to take the pills • Pill containers for cancer drugs should never be reused • Oral cancer drugs should not be crushed, split, broken or chewed. • It takes about 72 hours for the body to break down or get rid of most cancer drugs. During that time, a small amount of the drug comes out in urine, stool, vomit and blood. You should avoid any items that have been soiled with body fluids. Clothing, sheets and towels that have body fluids on them should be kept in plastic bags until washed, and should be washed separately from other laundry.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens after treatment for Stage III NSCLC?
Response.Content: After treatment is completed, you will be watched with an exam and chest CT with contrast every 6 -12 months for two years then a chest CT without contrast once a year after that.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is it safe to have physical contact with my loved one when they're being treated for cancer?
Response.Content: Although you need to take precautions to avoid coming in contact with cancer medications and body fluids, please know that it is safe to touch, hug and kiss your loved one while they are being treated with cancer medications. And, while it is usually safe to have sex with someone taking cancer meds, your loved one should discuss this with their health care team. Condoms may be required since the cancer drugs can be found in semen and vaginal fluid. Also, patients of childbearing age should avoid getting pregnant while taking cancer drugs. These are very powerful drugs and can damage a fetus and cause birth defects.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are there any foods or other medications that are dangerous for my loved one who is taking cancer drugs?
Response.Content: In addition to helping your loved one organize and take their medications, you can help them avoid dangerous food and drug interactions. Some cancer medications may interact with other prescription or over-the-counter drugs as well as herbal medicines and even some foods. The chances of a drug interaction increase with the number of medications being taken. This is very important because some medicines can affect how well cancer drugs work and may also cause adverse side effects or dangerous drug interactions. Take your loved one's list of medications to each doctor's appointment and make sure you ask about any possible drug/food interactions. You can also read the insert included with your cancer medication. It will list any possible adverse reactions with other drugs or food. For more information on drug interactions check out the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What should I do if my loved one misses a dose of their cancer medication?
Response.Content: If your loved one misses a dose of an oral cancer medication or throws up after taking the pill, call your health care team to find out when they should take the next dose. Do not give them a double dose. For most oral cancer drugs to be effective there needs to be a constant level of the drug in the body. Not taking cancer drugs as instructed can affect how well the treatment works and can make side effects worse.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I keep from getting overwhelmed?
Response.Content: As a caregiver to someone with cancer, it is extremely important that you also take care of yourself - physically, emotionally and mentally - so that you can continue to provide the best care and support to your loved one. Your emotional wellbeing can directly affect your loved one's state of mind so make sure you know the signs of caregiver overload and how to prevent it. Signs of caregiver overload are: •Being exhausted all of the time • Getting sick more often than usual • Not sleeping well • Feeling impatient, irritable or forgetful • Not enjoying the things you used to • Withdrawing from people If you're feeling overwhelmed, ask for help from others in your loved one's support system. You may also find it helpful to join a caregiver support group or speak to a professional about your feelings. One way to avoid getting overwhelmed is to make time for yourself to do things that you enjoy. Focus on the relationships that help support you. Maintain healthy habits like exercise, a good diet and getting enough sleep. Avoid things like alcohol or other substances that can affect your sleep and emotions.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I care for my loved one full time if I work?
Response.Content:
If your loved one needs full time caregiving, you may be eligible for Family Medical Leave through the Family Medical Leave Act or FMLA. This federal law guarantees up to 12 weeks of time off per year to care for a seriously ill family member. While you are on Family Medical Leave, your job and insurance are protected. Some states have similar laws that provide additional coverage beyond what the federal law mandates.
If you do take family medical leave, you will not be paid. This can be a financial burden for many people. Check with your state to see if they have programs to pay caregivers of people with serious illness. For more information on the FMLA and other assistance, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if I can't go to my loved one's appointments?
Response.Content: Even if you are not able to go to appointments with your loved one, you can still be a part of their health care team. When you are able, introduce yourself to their health care team and provide them with your contact information. You may need to have your loved one sign a release so that their providers can talk with you about their condition.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I make the most of visits with my loved one if I live out of town?
Response.Content: When you are able to visit your loved one, make sure to introduce yourself to the health care team and other caregivers if you haven't already. Meet with them and ask them if they have any concerns about your loved one. This is also a good time to step into the daily caregiver role yourself for a while. Not only will you be giving local caregivers a break, but it will also give you a chance to make sure that your loved one's living and care arrangements are working for them. And, of course, this will give you valuable quality time with your loved one.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I help with transportation?
Response.Content: Transportation to and from the hospital, clinic and doctor's office visits is a vital service for someone who is being treated for cancer. There are often several medical appointments each week and the side effects of cancer treatment can make it difficult to drive or take public transportation. If you live nearby and are able to drive, that's great. If you're not able to drive because of work or because you live too far away, you can help coordinate transportation for your loved one with neighbors, friends and other family who are willing to help out, or you can arrange for a car service or courtesy van from the hospital or clinic. Whether you'll be doing the driving or someone else, planning for the transportation includes knowing the exact address including suite number where the appointment is at, where to park and whether there is a parking fee, how far your loved one will need to walk and which entrance to the building is most convenient. Will your loved one need a wheelchair or other assistance to get to the appointment? And, how long will the appointment last? All of this preparation will make for a less stressful experience for both patient and driver. For other transportation tips, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Should I go to my loved one's health care appointments?
Response.Content: If you are able to go to appointments with your loved one your support can be very helpful. You can help your loved one write down questions that they have before the appointment so that they don't forget to ask them, and you can write down the answers to their questions when they talk with their doctor. You can also help by telling the health care team the symptoms and side effects that you've noticed your love one having. And, perhaps most importantly, you can be a second set of ears for your loved one, or you can take notes on important information.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I help my loved one with side effects?
Response.Content: Cancer symptoms and treatment side effects can impact cancer treatment, sometimes delaying or stopping future treatments. So, it's important for you as a caregiver to know what side effects to look for, how to treat them and keep them from getting worse. You should also know when to call the doctor about serious side effects. Even though reporting side effects may impact treatment, it is important that you and your loved report all the side effects that they experience. There are many things that health care providers can recommend to lessen side effects and keep your loved one's treatment on schedule. We'll go over the symptoms that your loved one may have and some things that you can do to help. Keep track of any symptoms and treatments in a log or journal and note the type of side effect or symptom, how often they have it, when it started, is there anything that makes it better or worse, how severe it is on a scale from 1 to 10, and how it is affecting your loved one's daily activities. Having this information available quickly can make it easier for health care providers to treat symptoms and side effects and may save you some trips to the doctor's office or emergency room. There are some tools to help you track symptoms and side effects in the tools area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I find care for my loved one if I live far away?
Response.Content: Even though you may not be able to act as primary caregiver, you may still have the responsibility of finding care for your loved one. Depending on what your loved one's needs are, you may be able to hire a professional home care service. These services can provide the level of care your loved one needs throughout their illness, from companions who can help with transportation, light housekeeping and other non-medical caregiver tasks to home health care aides and oncology nurses who can provide more skilled care and treatment. Some of these services may be covered by your loved one's insurance and there are state and local agencies that can provide financial support for these services as well. There is a list of these sources in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What other services are available to support someone with cancer?
Response.Content: There are often additional services available in your community for help with case management, transportation, meal delivery, and legal and financial help. For a list of these services, look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How long will I have to get chemotherapy?
Response.Content:
If your doctor prescribes chemotherapy for you, you will follow a schedule for treatment called a cycle. A cycle of chemotherapy means you receive your medication every 1-3 weeks. During each cycle, you will receive your prescribed chemotherapy.
Most people have 4-6 cycles of chemotherapy. Multiple chemotherapy drugs may be given in a cycle, and other medications to treat side effects are often be included in the cycle as well.

Response.BaseQuestion: Do you want to learn about the side effects to expect when getting chemotherapy?
Answer to question 009 No I don't want to learn about chemotherapy side effects.
Response.Content: Select the next topic you'd like to explore from the links to the left or the related questions, or if you don't see a topic you're interested in, type in a question of your own and I'll do my best to answer it.

Response.BaseQuestion: What will happen when I go to get chemotherapy?
Response.Content: If you are getting chemotherapy through an IV at an infusion center, before each chemotherapy session, you will be given a physical exam to check your blood pressure, pulse, breathing and temperature. Your doctor or nurse will ask you if you have noticed any changes from your last appointment. It is very important to tell them how you have been feeling or if you have any concerns. You will have blood work drawn to make sure your immune system is healthy enough to continue with your chemotherapy. You will be sitting in a chair that is able to recline. There will be space for one other person to come and stay with you. Your oncology nurse will start an IV or access your implanted venous access device or "port" if you have one. You will then get your pre-meds that will help prevent side effects. These may be pills or thru your IV. Your nurse will talk you through everything that she is doing. There is a curtain to pull for privacy. Most treatment areas have TV's. But you can bring an Ipod or tablet with you to use, or a book to read while you get your chemotherapy. When your infusion is complete, your IV will be removed and you will be able to go home. You may be drowsy from some of the pre-meds given.

Response.BaseQuestion: What should I know about oral chemotherapy medications?
Response.Content:
Some chemotherapy medications can be taken in pill form at home. These oral chemotherapy drugs are just as powerful as the ones that you would get at a treatment center. It is very important to take the oral chemotherapy medication how and when your doctor has told you.
There are a number of reasons why someone might not want to take their medication -- side effects can be challenging to deal with, and drugs that treat cancer can be very expensive. If you are concerned about how the oral chemotherapy is making you feel or the cost of the medications is becoming too much please call your doctor's office before you skip doses or consider cutting them in half.
Oral cancer drugs should not be crushed, split, cut in half or chewed. Also, your treatment will not be as effective and your cancer may get worse if you do not get the full dose that your doctor has prescribed. Your doctors and nurses know that these medications cause side effects and they can often suggest ways to manage the side effects that these medications have on your health. They also know how expensive the medications can be and can point you towards a less expensive treatment or help you find resources to help you pay for your treatment. If, for any reason, you are thinking about skipping treatments or changing the dose of any of your medications, please talk to your doctor or nurse before you do.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens after treatment for Stage IV NSCLC?
Response.Content: After treatment is completed, you will be watched with an exam and chest CT with contrast every 3 -6 months for three years then an exam and chest CT with contrast every 6 -12 months for two years. After the 5-year mark you will be monitored with a chest CT without contrast once a year.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the side effects of chemotherapy?
Response.Content: The side effects of chemotherapy depend on the individual and the dose of the medication you are on. They can include fatigue, nausea and vomiting, loss of appetite, hair loss, low blood counts, mouth sores and an increased risk of infection. Follow the links in the related questions area for more information about these side effects.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is bone marrow suppression?
Response.Content:
Bone marrow suppression is one of the most common side effects that causes cancer treatment to be delayed or changed. The bone marrow is the spongy tissue in the center of the bones that makes red cells, white cells and platelets. Some cancer drugs can cause the bone marrow to produce fewer blood cells. A drop in the levels of any of these cells can lead to side effects It can cause several significant dangers for cancer patients. One of the biggest dangers is infection. White blood cells fight infection. A low white blood cell count significantly increases your risk of infection.
There is nothing you can do to raise your white blood cell count on your own, but there are things you can do to reduce your risk of infection. They include: • Wash your hands often during the day, especially before you eat and use the bathroom • Shower or bathe daily,• Stay away from crowds • Avoid contact with anyone who is sick • Do not have dental work done while your white blood cell count is low. • Be careful not to cut or nick yourself • Wear gloves when working in the garden. • Avoid emptying or handling pet waste • And wear a face mask if your counts are low and you need to in a crowded area.
Even if you are very careful your body may still not be able to fight infections. Some symptoms of infection are: • Temperature at or over 100.4 degrees • Chills • Sweating • Painful urination • A bad cough or sore throat • Diarrhea. It is important to be alert to any change in how you feel and report any sign of infection to your doctor or nurse immediately If your white blood count gets too low, your doctor may prescribe a shot that can help your bone marrow produce more white blood cells.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is anemia?
Response.Content:
Bone marrow suppression can also cause anemia, which is a low red blood cell count. Red blood cells carry oxygen and nutrients throughout the body, so a low red blood cell count can make you feel very tired and weak. To see if you have a low red blood count, your doctor may order a blood test called complete blood count or CBC.
Symptoms of a low red blood cell count, or anemia, often start slowly, so you may not even notice them at first. However, as your red blood cell count gets lower, the symptoms will become more severe. The symptoms of anemia are: • Fatigue • Weakness • Shortness of breath • A racing heartbeat • Dizziness or lightheadedness • Headaches • Chest Pain • Or Pale skin. You should contact your healthcare team if you notice any of these symptoms. Get immediate help if you have chest pain, shortness of breath, racing heartbeat, dizziness or lightheadedness.
Depending your situation, your doctor may prescribe medication, an iron supplement, multivitamin, a high protein diet or even a blood transfusion.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a low blood platelet count?
Response.Content: Bone marrow suppression can also cause a low blood platelet count. A low platelet count puts you at increased risk of bleeding and bruising. Platelets are colorless blood cells that help blood clot. They line the inside of the blood vessel. When you have a low platelet count this layer thins and tiny drops of blood can leak through the spaces made when the layers thin. This can cause red dots on the skin called petechia (pa-TEE-kee-eye).

Response.BaseQuestion: What is pneumonitis?
Response.Content: Pneumonitis is inflammation of lung tissue. Difficulty breathing and a dry cough are the most common symptoms of pneumonitis. You may also have shortness of breath. Pneumonitis can be caused by some chemotherapy medications or radiation therapy to the lungs. Usually pneumonitis is treated with corticosteroid medications to reduce the swelling in the lung or its lining. Oxygen therapy through a mask or plastic tubing with prongs that fit into your nostrils may also be used to help you breathe While the swelling goes down. If you notice any of the symptoms of pneumonitis, we encourage you to call your doctor immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is diarrhea?
Response.Content:
Diarrhea is frequent and watery bowel movements. This side effect can be mild or severe. Mild diarrhea is having less than 4 liquid bowel movements in 24 hours. Severe diarrhea is having more than 5 liquid bowel movements in 24 hours.
If severe diarrhea is not managed it may cause serious problems, and can even be life threatening. If it is serious, your doctor may need to reduce your chemotherapy dose or even delay your treatment.
If you have diarrhea, let your doctor or nurse know. Your doctor may be able to prescribe medication to help you and may encourage you to try a low fiber diet high in protein and calories like: refined breads and cereals, applesauce, canned fruits, well cooked meat and fish.
If you are having liquid or frequent bowel movements it's important to keep your rectal area clean. You may need to use baby wipes and an over the counter barrier cream to protect your skin.
Also, be aware of the signs of dehydration which include • Increased thirst • Dry mouth and swollen tongue • Weakness • Dizziness • Palpitations or feeling that the heart is jumping or pounding • Confusion • Sluggishness • Fainting • Inability to sweat • And decreased urine output.
If you experience any of these symptoms we encourage you to call your doctor immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is nausea?
Response.Content: Nausea is the feeling of needing or wanting to vomit, and vomiting is the act of throwing up. Nausea and vomiting can become serious if it prevents you from taking or keeping down your medication, food and liquids. It can affect how well your treatment works and can make it necessary for the doctors to reduce your doses or even delay your treatment. There are medications your doctor can prescribe to reduce nausea and vomiting, so let them know if you are having problems with nausea or vomiting. Often times anti-nausea medications are given to you prior to receiving your chemotherapy. These medications can help to reduce the feeling nausea and decrease vomiting. To help with nausea try eating small, frequent meals and avoiding spicy, fatty, or sweet, or highly salted foods. Some patients also find music therapy and relaxation helps with nausea and vomiting. If you are vomiting it is important to replace lost fluids in order to avoid becoming dehydrated. Drink fluids throughout the day like water or flavored water, Gatorade, and juices. A good goal to keep you hydrated is to try to drink 8 ounces of fluid every 2 hours. Be aware of the signs of dehydration which include • Increased thirst • Dry mouth and swollen tongue • Weakness • Dizziness • Palpitations or feeling that the heart is jumping or pounding • Confusion • Sluggishness • Fainting • Inability to sweat • And decreased urine output. If you experience any of these symptoms we encourage you to call your doctor immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are skin reactions?
Response.Content: Skin reactions are a common side effect of cancer treatment. Reactions range from mild to severe and they can negatively affect your quality of life and some skin reactions can be serious and potentially life threatening. It is important to recognize when you have a change in your skin such as: raised, red areas, itching, hives, open or dry patches, peeling, blisters, or pimples on your skin. Your doctor or nurse will talk with you if these are common side effects to watch for from your chemotherapy medications prescribed by your doctor. We encourage you to call your doctor if you notice any of these symptoms.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is rash?
Response.Content: The most common type of skin reaction is a rash. It is often bright red in color and the skin may feel hot, burning or itchy. It typically appears on the face, scalp, and upper chest and back. Unlike acne, this rash does not have whiteheads or blackheads. The rash may extend over your entire body or in one area. It starts early in treatment, usually during the first two weeks, But can occur any time during your treatment. Rashes can develop into a secondary infection of lesions. You may also have other symptoms including: • Peeling of the skin • Wet or dry open sores • Fever • Swollen lymph nodes • And loss of appetite. If you notice any of these symptoms, we encourage you to call your doctor immediately. There are many other kinds of skin reactions caused by cancer medications. For more on those conditions and ways to manage a rash check our Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is skin darkening?
Response.Content: The darkening of the skin is called hyperpigmentation and it is a common skin reaction, particularly in dark-skinned people. This can occur as an overall darkening of the skin, or it can be localized, showing up in areas exposed to light as a golden brown or slate grey color change. Some drugs may also cause darkening of the tongue, gums, and over finger joints. Most skin reactions occur within two to three weeks after starting treatment and resolve 10 to 12 weeks after stopping treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does chemotherapy or radiation cause problems with memory and thinking?
Response.Content: Some people taking chemotherapy or radiation treatment may experience memory problems or a mental cloudiness, which is sometimes called "Chemo Brain". Patients often describe trouble concentrating, forgetfulness, trouble multi-tasking, taking longer to finish things and trouble remembering common words. For most people, these changes last only a short time, but for others it can go on for years and can affect your everyday life. So, tell your healthcare team about any changes in your thinking or behavior that begins to affect your lifestyle. There are also some physical conditions than can cause confusion. They include: • Dehydration • Anemia • Heart problems • A severe infection in your blood or central nervous system. • Thyroid disorders • Depression • Lack of Sleep • And alcohol use or abuse. Make sure you and your healthcare team rule out any of these conditions.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my hair fall out?
Response.Content:
One of the most distressing side effects from cancer treatments is hair loss, also called alopecia. The scalp is not the only area affected. Hair found anywhere on the body, including eyebrows, eyelashes, facial hair, underarm hair and pubic hair can be affected.
Not all patients lose their hair during cancer treatment. You may lose all your hair or just some; all depends on the kind of treatment you are getting. Some cancer drugs can also cause changes in the texture, color, and growth pattern of your hair. Hair loss doesn't happen overnight. It is usually a gradual process happening over one to three weeks after the first treatment. For others, it may happen over several treatment cycles.
Your hair will not instantly grow back once treatment is done. It may take three to six months after you finish therapy for your hair to grow back. Typically, hair loss is temporary, but when it does come back new hair may have a slightly different color, texture or curl.
If you do lose your hair you should gently wash your scalp and watch for any signs of infection. If you develop crusty lesions on the skin or scalp report it to your health care team. You may need to be checked for infection.
Hair loss can lead to depression, anxiety, and social isolation. It is also a constant, visual reminder of your cancer diagnosis. Choosing to wear a wig is a personal preference. If you decide you want to wear a wig, check with your insurance company. Many plans will cover part or all of the cost of a wig if your doctor writes a prescription. Ask for a prescription for an "extra-cranial prosthesis" that is, a wig! If you don't have coverage, call your local chapter of the American Cancer Society or your cancer center. They may offer free wigs. For more information on picking a wig or other options for head coverings, check out the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why doesn't food taste the same since I started treatment?
Response.Content: Taste changes are common during cancer treatment. About 50% of people getting treatment experience taste changes. The exact reason for this is not clear, but it might be a result of the damage to the cells in the oral cavity, which are especially sensitive to cancer drugs. Many people say they can no longer tolerate spicy foods and describe most food as tasting bland, bitter or like chemicals. These changes may occur during your drug therapy and last for hours, days, weeks, or even months after treatment stops. There are no medications to help with taste changes, but there are things you can do to increase your appetite. Make sure to call your doctor if your taste changes have caused you to stop eating and you have lost 5 pounds or more.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is prophylactic radiation?
Response.Content: Prophylactic radiation, meaning radiation to prevent the spread of cancer, is used for patients with small cell lung cancer because it is likely that cancer will spread, or metastasize, to the brain. This treatment uses a low dose of radiation and targets the entire brain, preventing tumors from forming. Although the dose of radiation is low, as with any treatment the side effects of this treatment must be measured against the potential benefits.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is whole brain radiotherapy?
Response.Content: Whole brain radiotherapy, or WBRT, uses small amounts of radiation to treat the whole brain. The whole brain is treated to kill even small numbers of cancer cells that are not numerous enough to be seen on scans. WBRT is generally given in 10 to 15 doses over two weeks. Many patients may receive WBRT in combination with another therapy such as surgery or radiosurgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: Question 010 Do you want to learn about the side effects to expect when getting radiation therapy?
Answer to question 010 I want to learn more about the side effects of radiation.
Response.Content: The effects of radiation therapy depend on which part of the body is receiving radiation. Make sure to talk with your doctor about what side effects you can expect and how to treat them.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the side effects of radiation therapy to the head and neck?
Response.Content: If you are receiving radiation therapy to the head and neck, side effects may include • Dry mouth • Mouth and gum sores • Difficulty swallowing • Stiffness in the jaw • Nausea • A type of swelling called lymphedema • and tooth decay.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the side effects of radiation to the chest?
Response.Content: Radiation therapy in the chest area can result in • Difficulty swallowing • Shortness of breath • Breast or nipple soreness • Shoulder stiffness • Pneumonitis • Esophagitis, • And radiation fibrosis, which is permanent scarring of the lungs from untreated radiation pneumonitis.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the side effects of radiation therapy to the abdomen?
Response.Content: Abdominal radiation therapy may cause nausea and vomiting or diarrhea, and radiation therapy to the lower abdomen can also cause difficulty holding your urine or bowel movements, and rectal bleeding as well as sexual problems and infertility in both men and women.

Response.BaseQuestion: How does radiation affect the skin?
Response.Content: Radiation can cause dryness, itching, blistering, or peeling of their skin. But these side effects often depend on which part of the body received radiation therapy. These skin problems usually go away a few weeks after you stop getting radiation treatments. However, if skin damage becomes a serious problem, the doctor may change your treatment plan. Radiation recall is a rash that looks like a severe sunburn. Although rare, it occurs when certain types of chemotherapy are given during or soon after external beam radiation therapy. The rash appears on the part of the body that received radiation. Symptoms may include redness, tenderness, swelling, wet sores, and peeling skin. Typically, these side effects start within days or weeks of radiation therapy. But it can also appear months or years later. Doctors treat radiation recall with medications called corticosteroids. Rarely, you may wait until the skin heals before continuing chemotherapy. For information on how to care for your skin, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a lobectomy?
Response.Content: Your lungs have 5 sections, called lobes. When a surgeon removes a whole lobe from your lung it is called a lobectomy. If necessary, part of the bronchus, the large airway, can be removed as well. This is called a sleeve lobectomy. These surgeries are done by a thoracic surgeon in an operating room and you will be given medication to make you go to sleep. You will also have a tube in your throat to help you breathe. The tube will not be removed until after you wake up from surgery and can breathe on your own. Recovery from a lobectomy depends on how much of your lung is removed and how healthy you were before surgery. You may experience shortness of breath for several months after the procedure while your lungs recover. This can be frustrating, especially if you were not having any trouble breathing before your surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a wedge resection or segmentectomy?
Response.Content: A wedge resection or a segmentectomy is done to remove a tumor and some of the surrounding healthy lung tissue if the surgeon cannot remove the whole lobe of the lung. These surgeries are done by a thoracic surgeon in an operating room and you will be given medication to make you go to sleep. You will also have a tube in your throat to help you breathe. The tube will not be removed until after you wake up from surgery and can breathe on your own. Recovery time from these surgeries depends on how much of your lung is removed and how healthy you were before surgery. You may experience shortness of breath for several months after these procedures while your lungs recover. This can be frustrating, especially if you were not having any trouble breathing before your surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a pneumonectomy?
Response.Content: If your tumor is close to the center of your chest, your doctor may recommend that your entire lung is removed. This is called a pneumonectomy. This surgery is done by a thoracic surgeon in an operating room and you will be given medication to make you go to sleep. You will also have a tube in your throat to help you breathe. The tube will not be removed until after you wake up from the surgery and can breathe on your own. You will also have a chest tube when you wake up from surgery. This is a tube that comes out through your chest to drain fluids, blood and air. Recovery time from this surgery depends on how healthy you were before surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is radiofrequency ablation?
Response.Content: Radiofrequency ablation is done when a tumor cannot be removed through surgery because of the patient's condition. In this procedure, the doctor puts a needle shaped electrode into the tumor and an electrical current destroys the tumor cells. RFA may be used to treat early stage tumors, or to reduce the size of later stage tumors. Microwave ablation uses microwaves instead of electrical current to destroy tumors. Depending on your condition, you may be given medication to make you drowsy and block pain, or you may be given medication to make you sleep through the procedure.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is stereotactic radiosurgery?
Response.Content: Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) is a large dose of radiation aimed very closely and accurately at a tumor. This treatment is used to treat brain metastases. Unlike traditional radiation, which is usually given daily over many weeks, SRS is given in either a single dose, called Gamma Knife� surgery, or in up to five doses, which is called Cyber knife� surgery. The accuracy of the Stereotactic radiosurgery beam allows a high dose of radiation to be delivered to the tumor, while leaving health tissue unharmed. Because of the need for accuracy with Gamma Knife surgery, you will not be able to move your head during surgery. A helmet or frame will be used to keep your head in place. Cyber knife surgery, however, uses a custom mask for each patient and a robot that follows a precise map of your skull to ensure accuracy. Cyber knife can accommodate larger lesions than gamma knife surgery and can also be used to treat other types of cancer outside the brain. Most patients can return to their usual daily activities after stereotactic radiosurgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens after treatment for Limited Stage SCLC?
Response.Content: After completing therapy for limited stage small cell lung cancer, you will have an oncology follow-up visit every 3 months during the first year and second year, every 6 months during the third year, then once a year after that. At each visit you will have a physical exam, and a CT scan of your chest and abdomen. You may also have a MRI or CT scan with contrast of the brain every 3-4 months during the first 2 years and bloodwork may be done if your doctor recommends it.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the side effects of immunotherapy drugs?
Response.Content: Side effects of immunotherapy drugs can include fatigue, cough, nausea, itching, skin rash, loss of appetite, constipation, joint pain, and diarrhea. Although immunotherapy drugs are sometimes said to have fewer and milder side effects than other treatments, that is not always the case and serious side effects may occur. Because immunotherapy drugs strengthen the effect of the on the body's own immune system, the immune system may start attacking other parts of the body, such as the lungs, intestines, liver, hormone-making glands, kidneys, or other organs. This can cause life-threatening conditions, so it's very important to report any new side effects to your health care team promptly. If serious side effects do occur, treatment may need to be stopped and you may get high doses of corticosteroids to suppress your immune system. It is important to tell your treatment team about the symptoms you have. They may be able to help. If you have chest pain or trouble breathing, call 911. If you have • A temperature over 100.4. • Stomach swelling, tenderness, or pain • Dark urine • Bloody or dark stool • Nausea or vomiting despite taking anti-nausea medications • Or Moderate to severe pain or cramps, contact your oncologist's office immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if my cancer treatment stops working / my cancer gets worse / spreads
Response.Content: There are many different types of cancer treatments and if one type of treatment doesn't work for you, your doctor may recommend a different treatment or suggest that you try a treatment that is being tested in a clinical trial. But there may come a time when you've tried different treatments but they are no longer controlling your cancer. If the available treatments are no longer effective, you should talk with your doctor about whether the risks and side effects of treatment outweigh any benefits you may get. It might be that it is unlikely that more treatments will improve your health or help you live longer. Even if this is the case, there are things you can do to help maintain or improve your quality of life. Supportive or palliative care can ease symptoms and manage side effects. For more information on Supportive Care options, look at the links to the right.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is genetic testing?
Response.Content: Allegheny Health Network offers specialized expertise in genetic testing and counseling. Not all cancer patients undergo genetic testing. Ask your oncologist whether genetic testing is recommended for your type and stage of cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a radiation recall rash?
Response.Content: Radiation recall is a rash that looks like a severe sunburn. Although rare, it occurs when certain types of chemotherapy are given during or soon after external beam radiation therapy. The rash appears on the part of the body that received radiation. Symptoms may include redness, tenderness, swelling, wet sores, and peeling skin. Typically, these side effects start within days or weeks of radiation therapy. But it can also appear months or years later. Doctors treat radiation recall with medications called corticosteroids. Rarely, you may wait until the skin heals before continuing chemotherapy. For information on how to care for your skin, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the side effects of chemoradiation?
Response.Content: Along with the separate side effects of chemotherapy and radiation, there are some side effects that are unique to chemoradiation. These include radiation recall rash, and esophagitis. For more information on these side effects look in the related questions area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Should I think about a clinical trial?
Response.Content: When you discuss treatment options with your doctor, you may want to ask about clinical trials. Clinical trials are research studies that test new treatments and decide whether the new treatment is safe, how well it works, and whether it is better than the treatment that is currently considered the best treatment. Clinical studies may test a new drug, or how well more than one treatment works together or whether a higher or lower dose of a drug is more effective. All of the treatments that people get for cancer have been studied in clinical trials and any future advances in cancer care will be due to people joining clinical trials. There are risks, as there are for any cancer treatment, but clinical trials are often where patients have access to cutting edge treatment and very close monitoring. For more information on clinical trials, look in Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What causes cough?
Response.Content: Cough is a common symptom of lung cancer. Sometimes a cough is caused by a tumor blocking or pressing on an airway, or by fluid in the chest. In these cases, treatment to reduce the size of the tumor or drain the fluid in the chest can help. Opioid medications can lessen coughing, as can cough medications with dextromethorphan which helps to reduce the feeling of needed to cough. If the cough is made worse by acid from upset stomach, nausea or vomiting, sitting upright or propped up on pillows can help. Your doctor may also recommend breathing treatments with a nebulizer to keep the airways moist, or suggest that you work with a respiratory therapist to help get rid of mucus in your lungs.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are adjuvant and neo adjuvant treatments?
Response.Content: Adjuvant and neo adjuvant are used to describe when and how a treatment is used with other treatments. For instance, if you have radiation before surgery, the radiation is called neoadjuvant, meaning before surgery. If you have chemotherapy after surgery, the chemotherapy is called adjuvant, or "in addition to" surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is constipation?
Response.Content: Constipation is infrequent passage of hard, dry bowel movements. Abdominal pain, bloating, nausea and vomiting and loss of appetite are all symptoms of constipation. Constipation is often a side effect of narcotic pain medications. There are some things you can do to prevent or relieve constipation. You can: • Eat foods high in fiber like fruits, cereals, and vegetables. • Drink two to three liters of non-alcoholic fluids each day; unless your doctor tells you otherwise. • There are also medications your doctor can recommend for constipation if these methods don't work.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I reduce fatigue?
Response.Content: Moving around may seem like the last thing you want to do when you are tired, but physical activity has been found to be one of the most helpful ways to reduce fatigue. The right level of activity depends on your lifestyle and health, so always talk to your health care team about what activities you can do safely. There are some things to remember when you start becoming more physical active: • Start slowly. This may mean just walking around the dining room table once. Try to do go a little further each time. This allows your body time to adjust. • Try to do some kind of physical activity every day or at least every other day. • The right kind of activity should never make you feel sore, stiff, or exhausted. • If you experience any of these feelings you may be overdoing it and it may be time to call your health care team. Also, tell your health care team if you experience any of the following: • Fatigue that limits your ability to care for yourself • Increasing shortness of breath with little activity • Uncontrolled pain • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or loss of appetite • Uncontrollable anxiety or nervousness • Ongoing depression. For more ideas on combating fatigue click on the resource tab.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is it normal to feel guilty?
Response.Content: Because many people think of lung cancer as an illness that is caused by smoking, may people feel that they are at fault for causing their own illness. They may feel like they are a burden on their family and caregivers or they may feel that others blame them and won't be as willing to help or support them. But lung cancer can affect anyone -- most people who get lung cancer today have either stopped smoking long ago or never smoked at all. Do not let guilt influence your treatment decisions.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF)?
Response.Content: Commonly called Neulasta or Neupogen, granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF or GCSF), also known as colony-stimulating factor 3 (CSF 3) is a medication that is given to increase the number of infection fighting white blood cells and prevent infections in people whose immune system has been weakened by chemotherapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I increase my appetite?
Response.Content: Many people taking cancer medications report a loss of appetite or no desire to eat. This can be caused by pain, depression, nausea and vomiting or advanced disease. It's important to eat healthy so that your body has the energy to fight the cancer. Some things that may help with your lack of appetite and nutrition are: • Eat small meals or snacks, every two to three hours, instead of three large meals a day • Eat foods that are rich in nutrients and high in protein or calories. • Avoid low-calorie foods • Drink nutrient-dense fluids such as milk, milk shakes, juice and punch-type drinks. • Avoid heavy meals, greasy or fried foods, and foods that cause gas. • Prepare food that is colorful and appealing to the eye. • Talk to your doctor about your appetite issues. There are medications that may be prescribed to combat lack of appetite. For more strategies to help with your appetite problems check out the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How does cancer treatment affect sexual function?
Response.Content: Cancer treatments can cause sexual changes for some patients. This is not unusual, and you are not alone. The most common issue is overall loss of desire. Just dealing with side effects from your cancer treatment may take so much energy that sex is not high on your priority list. For women, vaginal dryness and pain are often reported. For men, erectile problems are common. Most men and women are still able to have an orgasm, but it is common to need more time or stimulation to reach orgasm. If you are not receiving treatment for a hormone sensitive tumor, you may be a candidate for hormone replacement treatment. One of the most important things you can do is to share your concerns with your partner and talk to your health care team.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is catheter embolization?
Response.Content: Catheter embolization treats cancer using medications or man-made materials called embolic agents. These embolic agents are inserted through a thin tube into a blood vessel to block the flow of blood to a tumor.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the side effects of targeted therapies?
Response.Content: Although they have fewer and less severe side effects than other cancer treatments like chemotherapy, targeted treatments can have side effects, some of them serious. Common side effects are: High blood pressure, Too much protein in the urine, Nosebleeds, Rectal bleeding, Back pain, Headache, Changes in taste, Dry skin, Inflammation of the skin, and Inflammation of the nose, and watery eyes. Everyone reacts differently to medication and you may have different side effects. For a complete list of side effects for the medication you are taking talk with your doctor or pharmacist. More serious symptoms are rare, but tell your doctor immediately if you have any of the following symptoms: • trouble breathing, • swelling of ankles or feet, • sudden weight gain, • fast heartbeat, • signs of infection (e.g., fever, persistent sore throat), • muscle cramps, • muscle loss, • yellowing eyes or skin, • frothy or dark urine, • difficulty urinating, or • decreased amount of urine.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the difference between benign and malignant?
Response.Content: Tumors can be benign or malignant. Both are forms of cancer, but malignant tumors spread and harm other tissues. while benign tumors are growths that do not harm or spread to other parts of the body. Benign tumors may need to be removed if they are pressing on nerves, veins or other organs, but otherwise they are not harmful.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the symptoms of lung cancer?
Response.Content: Lung cancer may cause no symptoms at all until the tumor grows to a size that it affects other parts of the body near the lungs, or makes breathing difficult. When there are symptoms, they can include a cough that does not go away with treatment and becomes painful. If you have a cough that brings up blood or rust-colored mucus you should see your doctor. Shortness of breath, wheezing or noisy breathing and frequent lung infections such as bronchitis or pneumonia may also be signs of lung cancer. With many types of cancer you may experience a loss of appetite and unintended weight loss, and you may feel weak or unusually tired. At times, it is the metastases, or lung cancer that has spread to other parts of the body that cause the first symptoms. These symptoms depend on what part of the body the lung cancer has spread to. Symptoms from metastases can include bone pain, swelling or lumps in the face, arms or neck, headaches, dizziness, limbs that become weak or numb, or yellowing of the skin and eyes called jaundice. Most of these symptoms can be caused by other conditions as well, so it is important that you see a doctor to find out what is causing your symptoms. There are other symptoms that are caused by specific forms of lung cancer. For more information on these specific groups of symptoms, look in the related questions area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is cancer diagnosed?
Response.Content: No matter where you are in the process, the diagnosis of cancer can be a confusing and frightening experience. In order to tell whether your symptoms are due to cancer, your doctor will examine you and may order a number of blood tests, scans and procedures to figure out what type of cancer you have, how far it has developed and whether other areas of your body are affected. An accurate diagnosis is important so that your doctor can plan for the best treatment for you. We'll go over the tests and procedures your doctor may order to get the information needed to make an accurate diagnosis.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are lymph nodes
Response.Content: Lymph nodes are small, bean shaped organs that help to filter fluids in the body and fight infection. They are part of the lymphatic system which is a network of vessels, like veins. These vessels carry lymph, which is filled with infection fighting white blood cells. Because lymph nodes filter damaged cells, viruses and germs from the body, they are usually the first place in the body that cancer spreads to. The lymph nodes closest to the original cancer growth are called sentinel nodes. These nodes are often examined to see if a cancer has begun to spread.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is Horner Syndrome?
Response.Content: Cancers of the top part of the lungs, sometimes called Pancoast tumors, can damage nerves in the face and eyes, causing a group of symptoms called Horner syndrome. These symptoms usually affect only one side of the face and cause the eyelid to be weak and droop. The pupil, which is the dark center of the eye, will be smaller in that same eye and there will be reduced or absent sweating on the same side of the face. These tumors can also cause severe shoulder pain.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is superior vena cava syndrome?
Response.Content: Tumors in the upper part of the right lung can press on the large vein that carries blood from the head and arms back to the heart. This vein is called the superior vena cava or SVC. Pressing on the SVC can cause the blood to back up in the veins. This can lead to swelling in the face, neck, arms, and upper chest. Sometimes the skin in these areas looks a bluish-red color. SVC can also cause headaches, dizziness, and a loss of alertness. While these symptoms may come on slowly over time, in some cases they can become life-threatening, and need to be treated right away. If you have any of these symptoms, make sure to contact your doctor as soon as possible.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are paraneoplastic syndromes?
Response.Content: Hormones are chemicals that your body uses to get things done. They convert food into energy and break down the medicines that you take. They also help the immune system that fights disease in your body, and they carry messages from your brain to other parts of your body. Some cancers make hormone-like chemicals that cause problems in other areas of your body, even though the cancer has not spread to those areas. These problems are called paraneoplastic syndromes. The symptoms of paraneoplastic syndromes can be the first signs of cancer that you notice. Depending on what part of the body is affected, you may have symptoms including tiredness, loss of appetite and weight loss, weakness or clumsiness, changes in taste, smell, or sight, and problems with memory or thinking skills, or even sleep. Because these symptoms affect many different organs and can be caused by conditions other than cancer, doctors may need to do several tests to find out whether it is cancer that is causing your symptoms. If you have any of these problems, it's important to see your doctor right away so the cause can be found and treated, if needed. For information on specific types of paraneoplastic syndromes, look in the related questions area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone)?
Response.Content: When cancer cells make a hormone called anti-diuretic hormone, or ADH, it causes your kidneys to hold on to too much water, and lowers the amount of sodium in your blood. This is called syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone or SIADH. Although you may have heard that high sodium is bad for you, your body does need some sodium. Sodium helps carry messages from the brain to the rest of the body. So, if there is not enough sodium in your blood it can cause tiredness, loss of appetite, muscle weakness or cramps, feeling sick to your stomach and throwing up. You may also feel unable to stay still, and you may become confused. Without treatment, severe cases may lead to seizures and coma.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is Cushing syndrome?
Response.Content: Cancer cells may make Adrenocorticotropic hormone called ACTH. This hormone causes the adrenal glands to another hormone called cortisol. Cortisol affects blood sugar levels, helps change food into energy, reduces swelling, and helps with memory. It balances the amount of salt and water in the blood and helps control blood pressure. If too much cortisol is made, it is called Cushing syndrome. The symptoms of Cushing syndrome are weight gain, easy bruising, weakness, drowsiness, and the build-up of fluids called edema. Cushing syndrome can also cause high blood pressure and high blood sugar levels or even diabetes.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is Lambert-Eaton syndrome?
Response.Content: Cancer can sometimes cause the body's immune system to attack parts of the nervous system and weaken some of the muscles in your hips, shoulders, arms and legs. One of the first signs may be trouble getting up from a sitting position. Later, muscles around the shoulder may become weak. If the immune system attacks a part of the brain called the cerebellum it can cause loss of balance and unsteadiness in arm and leg movement, as well as trouble speaking or swallowing. This is called paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. These symptoms can also be caused by some cancer treatments so it is important to tell your doctor about any of these symptoms.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is hypercalcemia?
Response.Content: High blood calcium levels, called hypercalcemia, can cause frequent urination, thirst, constipation, nausea, vomiting, belly pain, weakness, fatigue, dizziness, confusion, and other nervous system problems. It can also weaken your bones, create kidney stones, and interfere with the way your heart and brain work.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is hypertrophic osteoarthropathy/ clubbing of the fingers?
Response.Content: Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, also called clubbing, is enlargement of the tips of the fingers or toes that happens when the soft tissue under the finger nails increases and bones thicken. It sometimes involves painful swelling of the joints.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is Thrombophlebitis?
Response.Content: Thrombophlebitis happens when a blood clot forms in a vein. The clot might be in a vein might be near the surface of your skin, which is called superficial thrombophlebitis; or the clot may form deep within a muscle, called deep vein thrombosis, or DVT. When the clot is in a vein close to the surface of your skin, you might see a red, hard cord that feels mildly painful to the touch. This type of blood clot usually goes away on its own after a few days. However, when the clot is in a deep vein, your leg may become swollen, tender and painful. This is a serious situation because the blood clot can break loose and travel to your lungs, causing a life-threatening condition called pulmonary embolism. If you have leg swelling and pain and the develop shortness of breath or chest pain that worsens when you breathe, go to an emergency room. These might indicate that you have a blood clot traveling through your veins to your lungs.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is gynecomastia?
Response.Content: Excess breast growth in men, called gynecomastia, is caused by an imbalance of the hormones estrogen and testosterone. Gynecomastia can affect one or both breasts, sometimes unevenly. Gynecomastia may go away on its own.

Response.BaseQuestion: What causes lung cancer?
Response.Content: Many people think that all lung cancer is caused by smoking. It is true that 80 percent of lung cancer is caused by smoking and exposure to second hand smoke. However, lung cancer can happen to anyone and has many other causes. The leading cause of lung cancer in non-smokers is exposure to radon gas. Other things that can cause cancer are asbestos, diesel exhaust, and other forms of pollution. Changes in DNA, called gene mutations, can also cause lung cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are metastases?
Response.Content: When cancer spreads from the part of the body where it starts to a different part of the body, it is called metastases. You may hear metastases called "mets". Even though the cancer is now in a different location, the cancer cells have the same structure as the cells in the original or primary tumor. So, even if lung cancer metastasizes to the brain, this "brain tumor" is actually made up of lung cancer cells. This is why cancer that has spread from its original location to another part of the body is described by the location of the original tumor. For instance, lung cancer that has spread to the brain is called a lung cancer metastases to the brain.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are monoclonal antibodies?
Response.Content: Monoclonal antibodies are drugs that use your body's own immune system to attack cancer cells. Antibodies are like markers that attach onto parts of cells called antigens. Monoclonal antibodies are made to attach themselves to the antigens on cancer cells. The monoclonal antibodies then attract other immune system cells and together they attack and kill the cancer cell. Monoclonal antibodies are injected into your vein. You may have a slight allergic like reaction to the injection, usually when you first start getting them. Compared to chemotherapy drugs side effects from most monoclonal antibodies are usually not as serious. They may include fever, chills, weakness, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, low blood pressure and skin rashes. Some monoclonal antibodies can have more serious side effects and you should talk to your doctor about the side effects of all medications you are taking.

Response.BaseQuestion: What tests are used to diagnose lung cancer?
Response.Content: In addition to a physical exam, your doctor may do other tests to diagnose or stage your cancer. These tests may involve taking blood from your arm using needle, doing imaging tests or scans using x-rays or magnetic or sound waves. Biopsies are tests that take samples of cells that are examined under a microscope to look for cancer cells. We'll go over the most common tests used to diagnose cancer, but your doctor may order other tests based on the symptoms you are having. If you have any questions about tests your doctor has ordered, just type them into the text box and I'll do my best to answer them.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an angiogram?
Response.Content: In an angiogram, dye is injected into an artery. When images are taken of the body along that artery's pathway, it can produce high-contrast images of internal structures.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a sentinel node biopsy?
Response.Content: Sentinel node biopsy has become a common way to find out whether a cancer has spread to the lymph nodes. If the cancer has spread, these lymph nodes are usually the first place it will go. Lymph node biopsies are done in an operating room. You will be given medication to make you sleep, and you will have a breathing tube in your throat. The breathing tube will stay in until after you wake up from surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is molecular testing?
Response.Content: Your doctor may recommend running molecular tests on tumor samples taken during biopsy. These tests look at the cancer cells for changes to genes that can help the cancer grow and spread. Knowing if and what mutations the cells in your tumor have may mean that targeted treatments are available to target specific weaknesses in the tumor.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is sputum cytology?
What is bronchoscopy?
Response.Content: A bronchoscope is a very thin tube with a light on the end. Doctors do bronchoscopy to see inside the lungs. There may also be tiny tools inside the tube that take samples of the lung or fluid surrounding the lungs so that they can be examined under a microscope. Depending on what type of bronchoscope is used you may either have general anesthesia that makes you go to sleep, or you will be awake, but will get medicine to block the pain and discomfort. If you're awake for the bronchoscopy, the back of your throat will be sprayed with a medication to numb it and prevent gagging. The doctor will put the tube through your nose or mouth then into your wind pipe and through the breathing passages of your lungs. There are different types of bronchoscopy. During a navigational or "virtual" bronchoscopy, your doctor uses CT scans to see your airways in more detail. For an endobronchial ultrasound, also called Radial EBUS bronchoscopy, your doctor uses an ultrasound probe attached to a bronchoscope to see your airways.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is thoracentesis?
Response.Content: Thoracentesis is done to remove fluid from the area around the lungs. You will be awake for this procedure, but you will get an injection to numb the area. The doctor will push a needle into the space between the lung and the chest wall. The fluid that is collected will be examined under a microscope for cancer cells.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is thoracoscopy?
Response.Content: Thoracoscopy is done to get samples of tissue from lymph nodes or fluid from around the lungs and heart. The doctor will make a small incision in your chest and insert a thin tube. The tube will have a video camera and light on the end so the doctor can see inside your chest. You will be given medication to make you sleep through the procedure and you will have a breathing tube in your throat during surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is mediatinoscopy?
Response.Content: Mediatinoscopy allows your doctors to look at and take small samples of the lymph nodes that are under the breastbone in the center of your chest. It uses a thin tube with a light on the end and very small tools that are used to get samples of tissue from the lymph nodes. This test is done in an operating room. The surgeon will make a small cut at the top of your breastbone to get to the lymph nodes. A second cut alongside the breastbone may be made to get samples from lymph nodes on the left side of your chest. You will be given medication to make you stay asleep while this test is done. After you are asleep, you will have a breathing tube in your throat. The tube will stay in until you wake up after surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is thoracotomy?
Response.Content: A thoracotomy allows the doctor to take larger samples from the lung for testing. It is also the same name used for surgery to remove a lung tumor. The doctor will make a cut in your chest.
