The location and size of the opening that the doctor makes in your chest depends on the location and size of the tumor or sample they will be taking from your lung. This procedure will be done in an operating room and you will be given medication to make you go to sleep. After you are asleep, you will have a breathing tube in your throat. The tube will stay in until you wake up after surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: How are scans used to monitor cancer?
Response.Content: Imaging tests, or scans, help doctors see where tumors are, their size and whether they have spread. There are many types of scans and the type your doctor orders will depend on the part of the body being examined. For more information on specific scans, look in the related questions area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a PET scan?
Response.Content: The PET in the term "pet scan" stands for positron emission tomography. For this scan you will be given a small amount of a radioactive sugar substance through a needle. The cells in your body use sugar for energy, so the areas of your body that are using the most energy will absorb more of the sugar substance than other areas. Cancer cells use a lot of energy, so these areas will absorb more sugar and will be more visible to the scanner.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an MRI?
Response.Content: MRI or magnetic resonance imaging uses a large magnet and radio waves to create pictures of the inside of your body. Patients with heart pacemakers, metal implants, or metal chips or clips in or around the eyes cannot be scanned with MRI because of the effect of the magnet. It is important that you don't move while you're getting an MRI, so usually this scan is not used to view cancer in the lungs. Most often it is used to view metastases in other parts of the body. You will be awake for your MRI and will have to lie or sit still while the image is being taken.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a Pulmonary Function Tests (PFT)?
Response.Content: Pulmonary function tests (PFT) measure your ability to breathe. They may be done after lung cancer is diagnosed to decide which treatment options are best for you. There are different types of PFTs, but they all involve having you breathe in and out through a tube that is connected to a machine that measures airflow.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why is it so important to follow my medication schedule?
Response.Content: You may be getting your cancer medications at your doctor's office or cancer center, or you may take oral chemotherapy drugs at home. Taking your medication how and when your doctor has told you to is very important. There are a number of reasons why someone might not want to take their medication -- side effects can be very difficult to deal with, and drugs that treat cancer can be very expensive. If you take oral cancer medications, you may be tempted to skip doses or cut them in half, but you should not do this. First of all, oral cancer drugs should not be crushed, split, broken or chewed. Also, your treatment will not be as effective and you may even make your cancer worse if you do not get the full dose that your doctor has prescribed. Your health care providers know that these medications cause side effects and they can often suggest ways to lessen the effects that these medications have on your health. They also know how expensive the medications can be and can point you towards a less expensive treatment or help you find resources to help you pay for your treatment. If, for any reason, you are thinking about skipping treatments or changing the dose of any of your medications, please talk to your doctor or nurse before you do.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I keep track of my cancer treatment?
Response.Content: Keeping track of your cancer treatment is very important. Although your health care providers will have your medical records, you may need to go to the emergency room or see another doctor that does not have access to your records. For this reason, always keep a detailed list of your medications with you as well as information on how to reach your oncologist. Also, keep a journal or notebook of all your doctor visits and treatments that you've had. Make sure your family members or caregivers know your treatment wishes so that they can relay them to a health care provider if you are unable to. Another way to keep track of your treatment is using the MyChart app. This free program enables users to check lab results, schedule or cancel appointments, review current medications, and message your doctor. Look in the Resources area for a link to MyChart and other information on tracking your cancer treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens after treatment for extensive stage SCLC?
Response.Content: After completing therapy for limited stage small cell lung cancer, you will have an oncology follow-up visit every 2 months during the first year, every 3 to 4 months during the second and third year, every 6 months during years 4-5, then once a year after that. At each visit you will have a physical exam, and a CT scan of your chest and abdomen. You may also have a MRI or CT scan with contrast of the brain every 3-4 months during the first 2 years and bloodwork may be done if your doctor recommends it.

Response.BaseQuestion: What precautions should be taken for people with weakened immune systems?
Response.Content: Infection is one of the biggest dangers for someone with a weakened immune system. Hand washing is the best way to prevent infection. Others things you can do to reduce the risk of infection: • Wash hands frequently, especially before you eat and use the bathroom and make sure that others around you also wash their hands frequently. • Stay away from crowds • Avoid contact with anyone who is sick • Be careful not to cut or nick yourself • Avoid emptying or handling pet waste • Wear a disposable face mask when you do have to be out in public • And, do not have dental work done while your white blood count is low. For more information look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Do cancer medications have any drug interactions?
Response.Content: Cancer medications may interact with other prescription or over-the-counter drugs as well as herbal medicines and even some foods. The chances of a drug interaction increase with the number of medications you take. You should keep a list of all the prescription and non-prescription medicines you are taking and share this with your health care team and any other health care provider you see. This is very important because some medicines can affect how well cancer drugs work and may also cause adverse side effects or dangerous drug interactions. Your list should include: • The name of the drug • The dose • How often you take it • Who prescribed it • And why you are taking it. Be sure you include any herbal and dietary supplements, vitamins and minerals and over the counter medications like aspirin. Also, eye drops, skin cream or patches. Even if the label says natural, homeopathic or organic it's important to consult with the health care team before a patient takes any kind of supplement. Double check with your health care team if you have any questions about medications you is taking. You can also read the insert included with your cancer medication. It will list any possible adverse reactions with other drugs or food. For more information on drug interactions check out the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are there any foods to avoid when getting cancer treatment?
Response.Content: Some foods can cause adverse reactions when taken with some cancer drugs. It's important to know what foods you should not eat when taking cancer medications. For instance, there is a substance in some juices that can change how a cancer drug is absorbed by the body. This can affect how a cancer drug works, making it either stronger or weaker. Grapefruit and its juice, along with Seville oranges, pomegranate and star fruit are some of the most common foods patients are told to avoid. Your oncology nurse can tell you what you should not eat or drink with the particular medication you are taking. For more information on food and drug interactions look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if I miss a dose of an oral cancer medication?
Response.Content: If you miss a dose of an oral cancer medication or throw up after taking the pill, call your health care team to find out when to take the next dose. Do not take a double dose. For most oral cancer drugs to be effective there needs to be a constant level of the drug in the body. Not taking cancer drugs as instructed can affect how well the treatment works and can make side effects worse.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is esophagitis?
Response.Content: Esophagitis is when the throat becomes inflamed and swollen. In people being treated for lung cancer, this may be an unfortunate side effect from radiation to the chest. It is particularly common in people who receive chemotherapy and radiation at the same time but can also happen when just radiation is being used. To prevent and manage esophagitis, there are several things you can do: • Eat soft foods. Avoid foods that may be sharp, like chips • Avoid spicy, citrus, or acidic foods • Avoid drinking alcohol or using tobacco products • Eat small meals throughout the day instead of three big meals. • Ask your doctor about pain relievers such as anesthetic lozenges or mouthwash. Try using them before you eat to numb your throat and reduce discomfort.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is Peripheral neuropathy?
Response.Content: Some cancer drugs can cause a side effect called peripheral neuropathy. 10 to 20 percent of patients experience this side effect. It is a nerve problem that causes pain, burning, numbness and tingling in the hands and feet. Other Symptoms of peripheral neuropathy are: • Numbness around the mouth • Loss of sensation to touch. Peripheral neuropathy can lead to difficulty walking and balancing which may increase your risk of injury from falls. The pain from neuropathy can lower your quality of life, impact your mood and keep you from being as active as you'd like to be. Peripheral neuropathy can be a sudden sharp pain, and it can become chronic and long-term If you are experiencing this side effect talk to your health care team. A combination of medication and therapies are often helpful relieving symptoms. For more information on peripheral neuropathy click on the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What role do caregivers play?
Response.Content: Whether you are a friend or family member of someone with cancer, as a caregiver you are an important part of the health care team. Caregivers fill many roles and these roles often change over the course of a loved one's treatment and illness. There are many ways to be a caregiver - it doesn't matter whether you live with the person you're caring for, or if you're 20 minutes or 200 miles away. We've gathered some information and tools that we hope you will find helpful at every step. The first part of this program is devoted to providing general information about lung cancer and gathering information from you about your loved one's diagnosis. The information you provide will help us focus on what is important to you and your loved one.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I adjust to life after cancer treatment?
Response.Content: Life after cancer treatment is different for each person, depending on the type of cancer they have and the treatment they received. Some people finish their cancer treatment and then see their doctor for regular follow-up exams and tests to make sure their cancer has not come back. Other people, whose cancer may never go away completely, may continue to get treatment to manage their cancer for as long as possible. Lung cancer survivors tell us that although they are relieved to be done with their cancer treatment, the period after treatment can bring its own set of challenges. After the shock and fear of the cancer diagnosis, treatment often gives people a sense of purpose around completing treatment and beating cancer. But when treatment is over, or they are receiving maintenance treatment to keep their cancer in check, they need to adjust to a new normal. Along with fears about their cancer coming back or getting worse, making this adjustment can cause feelings of anxiety and depression. No matter what your experience, please know that all of these feelings are normal. You have been through a physical and mental battle with a tough opponent. There are things you can do to help during this time. Look in the Resource and Related questions area for information on life after cancer treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is hypertension?
Response.Content: Hypertension or high blood pressure is another heart problem associated with oral cancer therapies. Most people don't notice any symptoms of high blood pressure. This is why high blood pressure is known as "the silent killer. Symptoms of hypertension are: • Elevated blood pressure greater than 139/90 • Slow heart rate usually slower than 60 beats per minute • Rapid heart rate • Chest pain • Decreased urine output • Bleeding that does not stop after a few minutes • Blood in your urine or stool. • Any unusual swelling in feet and legs • Weight gain of greater than 3 to 5 pounds in 1 week If you have any of these symptoms you should consult your doctor. If you suddenly experience nausea, dizziness, loss of vision, severe headaches, or confusion, chest pains or trouble breathing, seek medical help immediately.

Response.BaseQuestion: What can I do about dry mouth?
Response.Content: Dry mouth can be caused by a number of things, including medication, dehydration or fungal infection of the mouth. There are medications your doctor can prescribe to treat dry mouth, but there are also some things you try on your own can to help alleviate dry mouth. • Keep your mouth and lips moist • Rinse mouth with water frequently • Keep your mouth andteeth clean • Increase fluids • Eat a soft, high protein moist diet. • Avoid dry foods. For more ideas on treating dry mouth check out the resource center.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a fever?
Response.Content: Fever is an abnormally high body temperature. It is the body's response to infection, so you should call your health care team immediately if a have a fever of 100.4 degrees or higher. This could be a possible sign of infection.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is dehydration?
Response.Content: Dehydration is an excessive loss of body fluids and occurs when the output of fluid exceeds fluid intake. Dehydration can be caused by: • Vomiting or diarrhea • Infections • High fever • Bleeding • Or even something as simple as not drinking enough fluids Chemotherapy Dehydration is a dangerous symptom. It can be life threatening if the signs are not recognized and treated. Symptoms of dehydration are: • Confusion and disorientation • Dry mouth • Skin may appear loose and crinkled and will stand up like a tent when lightly pinched and pulled up • Secretions may become thick and dry. • Little or no urine output If you have any of these symptoms inform your oncology nurse you may need to get intravenous fluids.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I deal with feelings of fear?
Response.Content: No matter where you are in your cancer journey, it is common to feel fear. Initially you may fear the cancer treatments and side effects. After treatment, you may feel as though you're waiting for more bad news, and if your cancer returns or gets worse, you may fear of losing your independence and being a burden to your loved ones, and you may fear dying. Sometimes these fears hover in the background while you live your life, then suddenly surface again when you have a check-up or hear of someone else's diagnosis. Usually, these feelings come and go, and for most people they do not interfere with everyday life. But, if anxiety or fear keeps you from talking about your health, making doctor's appointments, or enjoying relationships with family and friends, it is time to talk to your doctor. There are things you can do to deal with your fears and your doctor may be able to help. For more information, look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: I'm feeling better can I stop going to treatment/taking my medications?
Response.Content: Do not make any changes to your medication or skip treatments unless your doctor tells you to. You may be feeling better, but you may still have cancer cells in your body and you need to complete your treatment cycle as directed to keep those cancer cells in check.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I remember what is in my treatment plan?
Response.Content: Your treatment plan is designed for you and your specific type of cancer. Sometimes it may seem confusing, but it is important to follow the treatment plan that your doctor has prescribed. Missing medication doses or other treatments can cause side effects and could affect how well the treatment works Making a plan and establishing a routine often helps people keep on track. If you are taking oral cancer medications at home, there are many tracking apps and other devices to help you remember to take them. For treatment schedules, you can use an online calendar that you share with caregivers, or you can simply use a paper calendar. For more ideas on ways to keep track of your treatment plan, check out the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my cancer come back?
Response.Content: First and foremost in the minds of many cancer survivors and their caregivers is "will the cancer come back?" Your chances of recurrence depend on many things, such as your overall health and lifestyle, the type and stage of cancer, the type of treatments you received and your family history. No one can tell for certain whether your cancer will return or not -- even if tests show no sign of cancer after treatment. Certain cancers can recur many years after first being found and treated. For some cancers, if it has not recurred by five years after initial diagnosis, the chance of a later recurrence is very small. Your doctor should discuss your chances of recurrence with you as well as ways that you can minimize the risk of cancer returning. While you don't want to ever think about the chance of having a second cancer -- one that's not related to the first cancer -- this is also possible. Having one cancer doesn't make you immune to having a second or even a third different cancer. It is entirely normal to worry about recurrence, especially during the first few years after treatment. These worries may increase around holidays and other special occasions - such as the anniversary of the date you were diagnosed with cancer. Many survivors report that this worry fades over time. But, if you find that your fears keep you from enjoying life and effect your sleep or eating habits, or if you avoid following up with visits because you fear finding out that your cancer has returned, it is time to talk with your health care provider. Having a sense of control over your health is key to reducing anxiety about cancer's return, so learn about your cancer and ask your doctor what you can do to stay healthy. Make sure to talk about your feelings with others. Many people find that just sharing their concerns with loved ones, or in a support group, can help them to let go of their worries. There are other suggestions for managing the concern about recurring cancer in the Related Questions and Resource areas.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I deal with stress?
Response.Content: Everything about cancer is stressful, but knowing when your stress level is too high and becoming serious is important. Some signs to look out for: • You have feelings of being overwhelmed to the point of panic • You are so sad that you think you can't go through treatment • You are unable to cope with pain, tiredness, and nausea • You have trouble getting to sleep or are getting less than 4 hours of sleep night • And you have trouble eating for a few weeks Talk to your health care team if you have any of these symptoms. There is a tool, much like a pain scale, that you can use to help measure your stress level. For more on this screening tool check out the Resource Area on this page.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are there any foods that I shouldn't eat?
Response.Content: Some foods can cause problems when taken with cancer medications. It is important to know what foods you can and cannot eat. For instance, there is a substance in some juices that can change how some cancer drugs are absorbed by the body. This can affect how the drug works, making it stronger or weaker. Grapefruit and its juice, along with Seville oranges, pomegranate and star fruit are some of the most common foods that patients are told to avoid. Your health care team can tell you what you should not eat or drink with the specific medication you are taking. You can also find this information on the insert that comes with your medication. For more information on food and drug interactions check out the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: I take pills for other health problems. Can I take my cancer drugs with those meds?
Response.Content: Before you begin taking any cancer medication, make sure you tell your doctor all the prescription and non-prescription medicines you are taking. This is very important because some medicines can change the way cancer drugs work. Make a list with the name of the drug, the dose, how often you take it, who prescribed it and why you are taking it. Take this list with you to your doctor's visit. Be sure to include any herbal and dietary supplements, vitamins and minerals and over the counter medications like aspirin. Even eye drops, skin cream or patches can affect how well your cancer drugs work and may also cause side effects or dangerous drug interactions Your doctor will tell you if you should stop taking any your medications before you start your cancer treatment. Make sure you always check with your doctor before taking any new medications or supplements.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I still take herbal supplements after I start my oral cancer meds?
Response.Content: Taking vitamins, minerals or other supplements may sound like a good idea if you're trying to eat healthy, but some supplements may change how well cancer treatment works, or cause life-threatening side effects. Even if the label says herbal, natural, homeopathic or organic it's important to consult your health care team before taking anything.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I spilt or crush my pills?
Response.Content: Doses of oral cancer medications are set up so that as the medications dissolve you have constant levels of the drugs in your body to kill cancer cells. If you split, crush or chew your pills it can affect how quickly the drug dissolves and is released into your body. This can cause serious side effects and can have a negative impact on how well your medication works.

Response.BaseQuestion: What should I do if I have trouble swallowing medication?
Response.Content: If you have trouble swallowing your medication tablet or capsule you should talk to your health care team. A liquid form of the drug may be available. Do not crush, split or chew your pills.

Response.BaseQuestion: What should I do if can't keep my medication down?
Response.Content: If you are throwing up your medication you need to tell your health care team immediately. A change in your treatment plan may be needed. Your medication doses are set up so you have a constant level of the drug in the body in order to kill the cancer cells. Changes to your dosage and treatment plan may be needed throughout your illness, but don't make any changes unless your doctor tells you to.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if I can't afford my medications?
Response.Content: Cancer treatments can be very expensive and may not be fully covered by insurance. This financial burden can weigh heavily on many people. It can also prevent some from following their treatment plan. If you're having trouble paying for your treatment, there may be help. Many drug manufactures have plans to help people pay for their drugs. Also, talk with your health care team. They may know about other resources to help cover the cost of your treatments.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I work while getting cancer treatments?
Response.Content: Many cancer patients who work fulltime continue working throughout treatment. For many, working actually helps to keep their mind occupied and off their diagnosis. If your work is physically or mentally demanding, doing your job may become more challenging, and you may need to adjust your schedule or your workload or you may even need to take some time off during your treatment. You are not obligated to tell your boss or co-workers about your diagnosis, but being open sometimes helps set realistic expectations, especially when asking for flexibility in your schedule and planning for absence. Before you talk to anyone in your workplace about your diagnosis, find out if you have and are eligible for short-term or long-term disability insurance at your job. If you do decide to talk about your cancer, have a face-to-face meeting with your supervisor and express a strong desire to keep working. Let them know that while you currently plan to continue working, your situation might change. If you disclose your diagnosis to your employer you may also be able to benefit from the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Family and Medical Leave Act. Keep in mind that what you tell your boss is protected information and should be kept in confidence. You can find out more about the Americans with Disabilities and Family and medical leave act in the resource center.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I deal with questions about my cancer at work?
Response.Content: When co-workers hear about your diagnosis they may want to show their concern by asking how you are doing. This may leave you feeling singled out as the "cancer co-worker", so when someone asks, say something like, "Yes, I feel terrific, and I'm really excited about the new software we're getting." This shifts attention away from your cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if I can't work during my treatment?
Response.Content: Sometimes, even with good planning and extra time off, it may be too much to keep working during cancer treatment. Talk with your health care team about how your treatment and symptoms are affecting your work. This may help you decide if or when you should to think about taking time off. Plan for possible disability early. Don't put off taking leave until your work performance suffers. If you are fired for doing a poor job, you can lose your health insurance as well as your income. And, if you're fired, you cannot collect disability benefits. If your treatment starts causing too many problems for you at work, talk to your supervisor. Explain that you want to keep working, but you need to take some time off. Talk to someone from your human resources department to find out if you have short-term or long-term disability insurance at your job. If you do, get applications for both -- just in case. In general, short-term disability pays you some portion of your income for the first few months you are unable to work. If you must be out longer, some employers also carry long-term disability insurance, which usually starts after 6 months of disability. You must meet the insurance company's definition of disability to get this income. Even if your company does not offer disability insurance you may still qualify for family medical leave under the FMLA program. For more information on this program, look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Oncologist (Text Only Mouseover Definition)
Response.Content: An oncologist is a doctor that treats cancer. Oncologists can specialize in specific types of treatment, such as surgical oncologists who use operations to remove tumors, and radiology oncologists who treat cancer using radiation, and medical oncologists who use anti-cancer therapy to treat cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Pathologist (Text only Mouseover definition)
Response.Content: A pathologist is a doctor who looks at cells under a microscope to determine if the cells are healthy. They help diagnose and stage cancer in cells that are taken during biopsies or surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: Respiratory Therapist (Text only mouseover definition)
Response.Content: Respiratory therapists use a variety of exercises, devices and treatments to help people breathe better.

Response.BaseQuestion: Oncology Nurse (Text Only Mouseover Definition)
Response.Content: Oncology nurses are the ones who deliver the day-to-day treatments of cancer patients. They are the ones who are there with you during your most difficult times. They provide education, encouragement and support while communicating with your doctors, coordinating your treatment and keeping you safe.

Response.BaseQuestion: Pulmonologist (Text only Mouseover definition)
Response.Content: A pulmonologist is a doctor who is an expert in lung diseases, including lung cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Should we get a second opinion? / Are there more tests we can do?
Response.Content: You always have the right to get a second opinion or to have more tests if you feel as though the diagnosis or prognosis may not be correct. Also, keep in mind that our renowned doctors provide high quality, compassionate care for every type of cancer and follow universally accepted treatment standards set by the National Comprehensive Cancer Network, an alliance of 27 leading cancer centers. Our physicians participate in Allegheny Health Network tumor boards where doctors discuss cases, get input from other physicians and healthcare providers to ensure that your doctor prescribes the best possible cancer treatment and care plan for you. We also belong to a Cancer Collaborative with Highmark and Johns Hopkins Kimmel Cancer Center which among other benefits, gives our patients access to experts in rare cancers and priority participation in innovative clinical trials. Another thing to keep in mind when considering a second opinion is that some insurance plans may not pay for consultations or tests that they feel are not warranted and you may need to pay for these services out-of-pocket. For more information on our relationship with Johns Hopkins Kimmel Cancer Center, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Prognosis (Text only mouseover definition)
Response.Content: Prognosis refers to what your doctor believes is going to happen over the course of your illness. This includes how long you are likely to live, and how the illness will affect your health.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is Supportive Care
Response.Content: Using supportive care services can help people with cancer at every stage to reduce stress, and improve their quality of life. And, supportive care can help prolong your life by as much as 33%. Supportive Care is care given to people who have a potentially life-limiting illness. It addresses the medical, emotional, spiritual and social needs of the person who is ill and their loved ones. Supportive care can begin anytime that a person is diagnosed with an illness that may be life-limiting. Medically, supportive care focuses on symptom care, such as pain management, managing shortness of breath, and treating any condition that reduces comfort or quality of life. It can be provided along with treatments to extend life or can be employed when life extending treatment has stopped. Supportive care can be provided in any setting -- hospital, skilled nursing facility, in hospice or at home.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is palliative care?
Response.Content: Palliative Care, sometimes called hospice care, treats people who are likely to die within the next 6 months. It can be provided in hospital setting, at a nursing home, in a hospice center or at home. If a person chooses to have palliative care, all efforts to cure or halt disease progression are stopped, but comfort care -- measures that ease pain and suffering -- continue. Patients suffering from other chronic conditions such as high blood pressure or diabetes will still be treated for that condition if it causes discomfort.

Response.BaseQuestion: What can I do to keep my cancer from returning?
Response.Content: Staying as healthy as possible is more important than ever after lung cancer treatment. Follow your doctor's recommendations for follow up visits and tests so that if there are any signs of recurrence they can be caught early. And as far as making changes to your lifestyle, you should follow the same guidelines that doctors recommend for cancer prevention which includes: quitting smoking, eating a diet low in red meat and processed meat, and rich in vegetables, avoiding alcohol, lowering your weight if you are obese, avoiding saturated fats and, being physically active for at least 150 minutes a week, and including strength training at least twice a week. There is no certain way to make sure that your cancer doesn't return, but following these recommendations can improve your overall health and lower your risk of recurrence. For more information on preventative care, look in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I decide when to discontinue treatment?
Response.Content: There is no right or wrong approach to making decisions about your treatment options. Treatment can change based on changing circumstances; for example, you can opt for full medical treatment until you are certain it will not cure your cancer or halt the cancer's growth, or until quality of life has gotten worse and cannot be made better. At any time, you can transition to more comfort measures and less medical measures. Or, you may decide to use life extending treatments until a goal is reached, such as the birth or graduation of a grandchild, a family trip, or the arrangement of financial and other affairs that are important to you and your loved ones. Also, these are not either-or options -- you can choose to continue having some cancer treatments and not others. Have this discussion with your doctor and make sure that your wishes are heard by creating a living will. For more information on living wills and other legal documentation, look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I document my/my loved one's decisions?
Response.Content: There are several ways to document end-of-life decisions. If a person is competent to make their own medical choices, they can have a living will drawn up by a lawyer and appoint a medical power of attorney to enforce their decisions. They can also make use of available free forms to document their wishes. Allegheny Health Network recognizes the Physician Orders for Life Sustaining Treatment form or POLST, which is available in the Resources area along with other free tools. Family members can also use these tools if their loved one is not able to speak for themselves. No matter what tools is used, it is important to make sure that health care providers are aware of these decisions. You can print out the POLST or other forms and give them to a health care provider to be put in the medical chart. You may also want to ask about "Do not resuscitate" and "do not intubate" orders if that fits with your plans.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I get my / my loved one's financial, etc. affairs in order before I / they die?
Response.Content: A lawyer can help you determine what affairs need to be put into order. A family member or caregiver can be named power of attorney to manage finances and complete paperwork. The forms and worksheets in the Resources section can help you determine what your needs are and guide you through the process of assembling the information needed to document financial and property decisions.

Response.BaseQuestion: Where can I find other sources of support?
Response.Content: There are many sources of support available to people with cancer and their loved ones. Your health care team can put you in touch with social workers, pastoral counselors and support groups.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is palliative chemotherapy
Response.Content: Palliative chemotherapy is used in cases where the treatment is not expected to cure cancer but only to prolong life or improve the symptoms. When deciding whether chemotherapy is the right treatment choice there are four factors to consider: The response rate of the chemotherapy--in other words how much will the tumor be affected by the treatment, how long will the response to chemotherapy last, what are the potential side effects of the treatment, and how long must treatment continue.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the goals of care?
Response.Content: Goals of care refer to what the patient or family member see as the desired outcome of their medical care. Possible goals for care are prevention, cure, extending life, or achieving a pain free death. A person may have multiple goals at the same time. For example, attempts to cure an illness can be made at the same time as efforts to relieve suffering and improve quality of life. Or, if someone has a personal goal that they want to reach such as getting their finances in order or seeing a loved one graduate or get married, they can receive life extending treatment along with supportive care until that goal is achieved, then stop that treatment in favor of palliative care alone when they feel ready.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who can tell me what benefits I have / talk to me about financial concerns?
Response.Content: Paying for medical care is often of great concern for people with cancer and their family members. Everyone wants the best care possible, but there are often very real financial concerns. Depending on what kind of medical insurance is involved, some services may be covered, others covered only partly, and others not at all. We've provided links to information on Medicare and VA coverage in the Resources area. If you have private insurance, you should contact their member benefits area to find out what kind of coverage you have and what it will pay for. If you are uninsured or unable to pay for medical care, Allegheny Health Network has programs that can help meet your needs. Contact information is in the Resources area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if my family members don't agree with my treatment decisions?
Response.Content: It can be difficult for family members to agree on care for their loved one who is dying. Everyone comes to acceptance of death in a different way and at a different pace. If one person has been closer to and providing more care for a loved one, they may more readily accept the doctor's prognosis, while others may still be in denial and see discontinuing medical care as giving up. Other family issues can complicate discussions and decisions around end-of-life as well. We hope that by sharing the link to this program with everyone involved in the decision process, you can resolve any differences among family members. Talking with social workers, clergy, the supportive care team or the ethics committee can also help families reach agreement.

Response.BaseQuestion: What should I do about follow-up visits?
Response.Content: It's important that you stick to your doctor's schedule for follow up. For some people, these follow-up visits cause anxiety and you may be tempted to put them off. Please do not delay or skip follow-up visits or tests. These visits are about more than just finding out if your cancer has returned --they are about understanding what to expect for the future and how you can regain control over your health. At your follow up visits, you can ask your doctor about any new symptoms you have, find out what long-term side effects to expect, and get support for life style changes such as quitting smoking or eating healthy. For information about getting the most out of your follow up visits, and for support to quit smoking, look in the Resource Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: Wbat is a treatment cycle?
Response.Content: Chemotherapy is usually given in cycles, which means you will have chemotherapy treatment followed by a period of rest from chemotherapy. A cycle can last one or more days, but is usually one, two, three, or four weeks long. A course of chemotherapy is a schedule of multiple cycles. For instance, your doctor may prescribe a 6-week course of chemotherapy that includes a cycle of two days of chemo and 5 rest days a week.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a treatment protocol?
Response.Content: Treatment protocols or clinical protocols are a set of guidelines that doctors follow to treat different forms of illness. These guidelines tell doctors what treatments to give a patient depending on what cancer the patient has and how far it has progressed. It also tells them what side effects and symptoms might happen and how to treat them if they do.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do the lungs work?
Response.Content: You probably know that your lungs take in oxygen when you breathe in, and that they get rid of carbon dioxide when you breathe out. But how does that happen? As you inhale air through your mouth and nose, the air heads down your trachea, or windpipe. The air flows through branching tubes in your lungs, called the bronchi and the bronchioles. These bronchioles end in the tiny air sacs called alveoli. Blood that is pumped from the heart to the lungs picks up oxygen from the alveoli and carries it to cells all over the body. As it travels around to your cells, it exchanges oxygen for carbon dioxide which is made by your cells. After it makes its way around your body and is full of carbon dioxide, the blood comes back through heart and to the lungs where it drops off the carbon dioxide in the alveoli. The carbon dioxide is then pushed out of the lungs when you breathe out.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is anti-angiogenesis?
Response.Content: Anti-angiogenesis means to stop new blood vessels from forming. Anti-angiogenesis medications prevent tumors from forming new blood vessels. Tumors need lots of oxygen and energy to grow, so without a steady supply of blood from new blood vessels, they will starve and die.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a physical exam?
Response.Content: You've probably had a physical exam before, where your doctor listens to your heart, your lungs, and your stomach. Your doctor may also press on parts of your body to see if your organs are their normal size, and to see if they are hard or soft or if they cause pain when touched. Your doctor will also look at how well you can do daily activities. A physical exam is not usually enough for a doctor to make a diagnosis of cancer, so other tests may be needed.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a tumor?
Response.Content: A tumor is really any unusual swelling or growth of tissues in the body. It can be described as a nodule, a bump, a lump or a mass. Sometimes tumors are cancer and these are called malignant tumors. Sometimes tumors will not spread and damage other tissues. These tumors are called benign.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is Keytruda?
Response.Content: Keytruda or Pembrolizumab is an immunotherapy drug that treats some cancers with the PD-1 mutation, no matter where the cancer is in the body. For more information on this treatment, please look in the Resources area or ask your doctor.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the types of radiation therapy?
Response.Content: There are several different forms of radiation treatment. What type you receive will depend on your diagnosis, if your cancer has spread, where it has spread and what symptoms you are having.

Response.BaseQuestion: What can I expect when undergoing surgery for my lung cancer?
Response.Content: These surgeries are done by a thoracic surgeon in an operating room and you will be given medication to make you go to sleep. You will also have a tube in your throat to help you breathe. The tube will not be removed until after you wake up from surgery and can breathe on your own. Recovery time from these surgeries depends on how much of your lung is removed and how healthy you were before surgery. You may experience shortness of breath for several months after these procedures while your lungs recover. This can be frustrating, especially if you were not having any trouble breathing before your surgery.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I know what treatment to get?
Response.Content: Your doctor will discuss your treatment options with you and talk about what the goals of each treatment option are. Depending on your prognosis, some treatments are done in hopes that they will cure your cancer. Others are done to slow the spread of the disease. These are called medical treatments. Other treatments are done only to lessen the symptoms of cancer and make you more comfortable. These are called supportive or palliative care services. Supportive care services can be used at any time during your illness, alongside medical care or alone. When discussing your prognosis and treatment options, make sure to tell your doctor what your goals for treatment are and to ask what outcomes are realistic to expect from each treatment option. This can help you decide what treatments are right for you. Treatment can change based on changing circumstances, for example you can opt for full medical treatment until you are certain it will not cure or halt the disease progression or until quality of life has gotten worse and cannot be made better. Then, when you are ready, you can transition to more comfort measures and less medical measures.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do I talk to my loved ones about my diagnosis
Response.Content: Cancer is a frightening diagnosis and discussing cancer can be uncomfortable for the person with cancer as well as for family members, caregivers and other loved ones. The person with cancer may wish to spare their loved ones from the possibility that they may die, and caregivers may be uncomfortable thinking about the fact they too will die one day, or they may not want to break down or upset their loved one by showing too much emotion. Although it can be difficult, most people are relieved to talk openly about these issues. It's important to let the other person know how you are feeling about having this discussion, be open about your emotions, your needs and what you're able to handle. Some people need to talk about their feelings, beliefs and fears around dying, others may prefer only succinct, factual discussions. Open communication is the key to any discussion about cancer. Social workers, clergy, or members of your health care team can also be helpful with this.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who is on my care team?
Response.Content: Your care team includes your medicaloncologist, who is the doctor who will coordinate your cancer treatment and prescribe cancer fighting medications; as well as other cancer specialists who may treat your cancer such as a surgical oncologist who removes tumors and does some types of biopsies, or a radio oncologist who treats cancer with radiation. You may also have a thoracic surgeon who specializes in operating on the chest. You will also be cared for by oncology nurses, and an oncology social worker or patient navigator who guides patients and their families through the health care system and helps them work with other team members to make sure they can complete treatment. Other professionals who are involved in your care include a pathologist who looks at the results of tests such as blood tests or biopsies to diagnose cancer, and a radiologist who diagnoses cancer by looking at the results of x-rays CT, PET, or MRI scans. Your oncologist may refer you to other specialists depending on your needs, including a supportive care or palliative care physician who focuses on meeting patients' physical, emotional, spiritual and social needs over the course of their illness, a dietician who can help with nutritional needs such as loss of appetite, and chewing and swallowing issues, and, also, a physical therapist who can help you improve your strength and activity level.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the risk factors for lung cancer?
Response.Content: Smoking is often thought of as the main risk factor for lung cancer, but having a risk factor, or even several, does not mean that you will get the disease. And some people who get lung cancer may have few or no known risk factors. Factors that increase your risk of having lung cancer include: Smoking tobacco of any kind, including low tar and menthol cigarettes, cigars, and pipes. Your risk of developing lung cancer increases the longer you smoke and the more packs a day you smoke. Smokers who take beta carotene supplements have an even higher rate of lung cancer than smokers who do not take the supplements. Secondhand smoke, breathing the tobacco smoke of others even though you do not smoke yourself, also increases your risk of developing lung cancer. Exposure to other things in the environment such as radon gas, asbestos, diesel exhaust, arsenic and other chemicals and higher levels of air pollution in cities and near roadways are also risk factors. Having a prior diagnosis of lung cancer puts you at a higher risk for developing another lung cancer. And, a close family member with a history of lung cancer, especially if they were diagnosed at a younger age, signals an increased risk as well.

Your doctor can help by prescribing medications to reduce your cravings and counseling can help as well. Please, talk to your healthcare team about quitting smoking and other tobacco use today. Response.BaseQuestion: What pre-surgery tests will I need?
Response.Content: Before surgery your surgical oncologist will want you to have some tests in addition to standard pre-surgery bloodwork. These include imaging tests such as CT or PET scans, and possibly an MRI scan. A pulmonary function test is important to show the surgeon how well you're able to breath and how much lung tissue can be removed. And, a stress test may be done to see how well your heart is functioning. You may have had some of these tests when your medical oncologist was diagnosing your cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I prepare for surgery?
Response.Content: The number one thing you can do to prepare yourself for lung cancer surgery is to stop using any tobacco products as soon as possible. Not only does smoking affect the health of your lungs and other organs, but any form of tobacco use slows down the healing process. Your doctor may ask you to use a spirometer before surgery to strengthen your lungs and the muscles in your chest that help you to breath. Using a spirometer regularly before surgery can have a big impact on your recovery after surgery. There is information on spirometer use in the Resources area. Also, stay as active as possible leading up to your surgery, eat a good diet, and follow the pre-surgery instructions that your health care team gives you. There is more information on preparing for surgery in the Resources area.

Response.Content: There are a number of tools available to help you make and document your treatment goals and decisions. In Pennsylvania, the POLST or Physician Orders for Life Sustaining Treatment form guides you through a discussion with your physician about your condition, prognosis, treatment options, and goals of care. Once the form is filled out by you and your doctor it is a medical order that healthcare and emergency personnel can follow even if you cannot speak for yourself. Response.BaseQuestion: How can I keep my loved-ones safe while I'm taking cancer medications?
Response.Content: Cancer medications are powerful drugs whether they are given in a doctor's office or taken at home. These drugs don't just affect cancer cells -- they can be harmful to healthy cells as well. For this reason, people who are not being treated for cancer should not have contact with any cancer drugs, including chemotherapy, hormones, and targeted therapies. These should all be regarded as hazardous drugs. If you take oral chemotherapy drugs at home, you should keep your medications away from other family members and pets. Your family members should wear disposable gloves if they must help you with your medications because even small amounts can be dangerous to them. If you touch your medications, you should wash your hands before touching anything else. The outsides of bottles or blister packs may also contain traces of the drugs. Even though it may only be a trace amount, it can be absorbed through skin, inhaled, or ingested or can transfer to surfaces if not handled properly. Pregnant caregivers should never handle oral cancer medications. Look in the related questions for other information on safe handling. It takes about 72 hours for the body to break down or get rid of most cancer drugs. During that time, a small amount of the drug comes out in urine, stool, vomit and blood. Items soiled with body fluids should be kept in plastic bags until washed, and should be washed separately from other laundry. Pregnant caregivers should be very careful to not come in contact with oral cancer medications or your body fluids. Low-pressure toilets should be double-flushed after use by people taking oral cancer drugs. And, always close the toilet lid before flushing. For more information on medication safety, look at the related questions area of this page.

Response.BaseQuestion: How can I manage work while in treatment?
Response.Content: Side effects from cancer treatments can make working through treatment a challenge. Cancer treatments can affect your memory and your ability to think clearly. Some people find that using additional reminders can help them. You can use sticky notes; keep a calendar, record messages on your smart phone--whatever it takes to help you keep track of appointments, meetings and deadlines. There are other things that may help you keep working through treatment, for instance: • If possible, work from home some days. This might help you save energy and allow you to take care of yourself more easily if you have problems. • If possible, get help at home with daily chores like housekeeping and cooking. This will help you conserve energy. • If your co-workers know about your situation they may be able to help you come up with ways to better manage your work. • Keep your supervisor up to date on how your schedule or other changes are working for you. • Make a detailed list of job duties, so you can direct others in handling things when you're out of the office • Set limits. If you start to feel tired take a break. Don't overdo it.

Response.BaseQuestion: When will I start treatment
Response.Content: Once you are diagnosed, you may want to start treatment as soon as possible. However, there may be some additional procedures that you need to go through before your treatment actually beings. Depending on your type of cancer and what tests you've already had, your doctor may need for you to have tests or scans done to accurately stage your cancer. If you will be having chemotherapy or other treatment delivered by an IV, you may have to have a port or catheter inserted under your skin to make treatments easier to administer. There may also be insurance authorizations and other paperwork that you need to complete before treatment starts. Talk to your cancer care team to see what steps need to be taken so that you can start your treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are blood tests?
Response.Content: Doctors use blood tests to look for signs of cancer in your blood. A complete blood count or CBC looks at how many red and white blood cells and platelets are in your blood. Cancer and other illnesses can cause high or low numbers of these cells. Doctors also look at other chemicals in your blood that come from your liver, bone or other organs. This chemistry profile can help your doctor tell whether your cancer has spread to other organs or if you have other health problems.

Response.BaseQuestion: Survivorship Care
Response.Content: As a cancer survivor, it is important to follow your doctor's recommendations for healthy living and to continue to receive screenings for the usual health problems. But, you should pay particular attention to annual vaccinations for the flu and pneumonia as well as getting a shingles vaccine. Monitoring your blood pressure, cholesterol, and glucose levels is especially important as well. Bone density can be affected by some cancer treatments, so bone density scans are recommended, and you should continue to get regular dental checkups. Be sure to wear sun screen whenever you are outdoors. It is important to eat a healthy diet, get at least 30 minutes of exercise most days of the week, and limit the amount of alcohol you drink. Talk to you doctor to see if there are any additional recommendations that you should follow to reduce your risk of recurrence or developing other cancers. For more information on life after cancer treatment, look in the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is performance status?
Response.Content: Performance status is the standard criteria for measuring how the disease impacts a patient's daily living abilities. It describes a patient's level of functioning in terms of their ability to care for themselves, daily activity, and physical ability, for instance walking or working, etc. For more information on how healthcare providers determine performance status, look in the Resources Area.

Response.BaseQuestion: New advances in cancer treatments
Response.Content: You may hear about new cancer tests and treatments in the news as researchers uncover new insights. But keep in mind that many of the advances you hear about are still in the experimental stage and may only be available through participation in clinical trials for patients who meet the eligibility requirements. If you have questions about tests or treatments that you've heard about, ask your Cancer Care Navigator or Oncologist. They can tell you whether the treatment is appropriate for your type of cancer and whether it is available outside of a clinical trial. You can find information on clinical trials by visiting the Clinical Trials website using the link in the Resources Area.

394 Okay, I'll listen to the prognosis information
I'm glad you've decided to find out more about your prognosis. Here are some things to remember when learning about your prognosis. Doctors often use the 5-year survival rate when talking about prognosis. This is the percentage of people at least 5 years after their cancer diagnosis. But many people live longer -- often much longer -- than 5 years. For example, a 5-year survival rate of 50% means that an estimated 50 out of 100 people who have that cancer are still alive 5 years after being diagnosed. And many of those people have many years yet to go. These numbers can't tell you how long you will live, but they may help give you a better understanding about how likely it is that your treatment will be useful. Keep in mind as you hear this information that statistics are estimates, educated guesses that describe trends in large numbers of people. These statistics do not necessarily predict what will actually happen to you.
